While OT administration led to a relative increase of neural activation in mesolimbic structures during processing of erotic stimuli, it decreased amygdala activation for fearful stimuli. On the individual level, we observed significant positive correlations between OT induced activation changes across different brain regions and under different stimulus conditions. Our findings extend the already existing animal literature and provide evidence for a similar involvement of the mesolimbic dopaminergic system for OT effects in the context of reproduction and attachment in humans.
studies.journal: International journal of psychophysiology : official journal of the International Organization of Psychophysiology
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Task-based fMRI study (double-blind, placebo-controlled) in 55 healthy young men viewing attachment-related erotic and fearful social scenes; directly examines social-related processing in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=55 males, mean age 24.9) using a social-related task (processing of erotic and fearful social scenes and faces). The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., erotic>neutral, fearful>neutral, erotic>fearful) with significance thresholds reported for whole-brain FWE-corrected results and ROI analyses; coordinates and figures/tables of whole-brain effects are provided. Thus it meets the review objective and satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state/connectivity-only, between-group-only, non-empirical, or age-out-of-range) are met.

studies.title: Seeing minds in others: Mind perception modulates low-level social-cognitive performance and relates to ventromedial prefrontal structures.
studies.abstract: In social interactions, we rely on nonverbal cues like gaze direction to understand the behavior of others. How we react to these cues is affected by whether they are believed to originate from an entity with a mind, capable of having internal states (i.e., mind perception). While prior work has established a set of neural regions linked to social-cognitive processes like mind perception, the degree to which activation within this network relates to performance in subsequent social-cognitive tasks remains unclear. In the current study, participants performed a mind perception task (i.e., judging the likelihood that faces, varying in physical human-likeness, have internal states) while event-related fMRI was collected. Afterwards, participants performed a social attention task outside the scanner, during which they were cued by the gaze of the same faces that they previously judged within the mind perception task. Parametric analyses of the fMRI data revealed that activity within ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) was related to both mind ratings inside the scanner and gaze-cueing performance outside the scanner. In addition, other social brain regions were related to gaze-cueing performance, including frontal areas like the left insula, dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, and inferior frontal gyrus, as well as temporal areas like the left temporo-parietal junction and bilateral temporal gyri. The findings suggest that functions subserved by the vmPFC are relevant to both mind perception and social attention, implicating a role of vmPFC in the top-down modulation of low-level social-cognitive processes.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI was collected while participants performed a mind-perception task and related social attention was examined, satisfying I1 (social-related fMRI). The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they were healthy adults, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify I2.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study acquired task-based fMRI during a mind-perception/social attention paradigm and reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses. Participants were healthy adults (N=22, mean age 24.36), within the 18–65 range. The paper describes whole-brain, cluster-corrected results (parametric analyses, conjunctions) identifying vmPFC and other regions and provides tables/figures of these group-level activation maps. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults and reports whole-brain healthy-group task effects.

studies.title: Neural processing of the own child's facial emotions in mothers with a history of early life maltreatment.
studies.abstract: Early life maltreatment (ELM) has long-lasting effects on social interaction. When interacting with their own child, women with ELM often report difficulties in parenting and show reduced maternal sensitivity. Sensitive maternal behavior requires the recognition of the child's emotional state depicted in its facial emotions. Based on previous studies, it can be expected that ELM affects the neural processing of facial emotions by altering activation patterns in parts of the brain's empathy and mentalizing networks. However, so far studies have focused on the processing of standardized, adult facial emotions. Therefore, the current study investigated the impact of ELM on the processing of one's own child's facial emotions using functional magnetic resonance imaging. To achieve this, 27 mothers with and 26 mothers without a history of ELM (all without current mental disorders and psychopharmacological treatment) took part in an emotional face recognition paradigm with happy, sad, and neutral faces of their own and an unknown primary school-aged child of the same age and sex. We found elevated activations in regions of the mentalizing (superior temporal sulcus, precuneus) and mirror neuron (inferior parietal lobule) networks as well as in the visual face processing network (cuneus, middle temporal gyrus) in mothers with ELM compared to the non-maltreated mothers in response to happy faces of their own child. This suggests a more effortful processing and cognitive empathic mentalizing of the own child's facial happiness in mothers with ELM. Future research should address whether this might indicate a compensatory recruitment of mentalizing capacities to maintain maternal sensitivity.
studies.journal: European archives of psychiatry and clinical neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used fMRI during an emotional face recognition task (processing own child’s facial emotions), a social-processing task. Adult mothers included a healthy control group (mothers without ELM). Thus it meets I1 and I2.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study examining mothers (adult participants) processing their own child’s facial emotions — a clear social-related task (perception/understanding of others). The sample includes a healthy control group of adult mothers without lifetime mental disorder reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation results (e.g., own>unknown child contrast with FWE-corrected whole-brain results and within-group effects reported for the control group, e.g., medial frontal gyrus), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Results are presented as ROI and whole-brain analyses and coordinates/statistics are reported. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Thinking about the past to shape the present: neural activation during the recall of relationship episodes.
studies.abstract: Reflecting on oneself and others in relationships is an ability that is central to our social existence. Specifically, considering formative autobiographical experiences in relationships may contribute to more flexibility in perceiving, as well as in shaping present relationships. Reflecting on such experiences mobilizes different social cognitive and affective processes. We aim to explore the neural basis of these processes. With a newly developed functional magnetic imaging (fMRI) task, we investigated brain activation in 35 healthy individuals during recall of relationship episodes involving themselves or others. We found that recalling formative episodes involving themselves modulated brain activity in the right parahippocampus, left precuneus, bilateral fusiform gyrus, bilateral insula, and left presupplementary motor area. These areas are involved in memory processes, self-generated thought, and affective experience. The recall of relationship episodes involving others led to similar activation patterns. Our results underscore the close link between self-reflection, understanding others, and memory processes and emphasize the role of affective dimensions for self-relevant experiences. They contribute to a growing body of research on neural mechanisms involved in complex social cognitive processes decisive for our capacity to navigate our social environment.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI task probing recall of relationship episodes (self/others) in 35 healthy individuals—fits social-related processing and fMRI (I1). Age range (18–65) is not reported in the abstract, so inclusion should be confirmed at full-text stage (I2 not verifiable from abstract). Include for full-text review to verify participant ages and other details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The paper reports a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (recall of formative relationship episodes involving self vs. others), addressing social cognition constructs such as self-/other-referencing and attachment. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=35, mean age 33.85) screened to exclude mental disorders. The authors report group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., self-relevant>control, other>control) with FDR cluster correction and provide tables/figures of significant clusters and coordinates. These whole-brain results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, participants are within age range, and it is an empirical fMRI study).

studies.title: Oxytocin Facilitates Approach Behavior to Positive Social Stimuli via Decreasing Anterior Insula Activity.
studies.abstract: The neuropeptide oxytocin can extensively modulate human social behavior and affective processing, and its effects can be interpreted in terms of mediating approach-avoidance motivational processes. However, little is known about how oxytocin mediates approach-avoidance behavior and particularly the underlying neural mechanisms.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract suggests neural effects of oxytocin on social stimuli (anterior insula) but does not explicitly state fMRI or participant characteristics. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria from abstract alone; include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It uses task-based fMRI during a social-related approach-avoidance task contrasting social vs nonsocial stimuli (relevant to social processing constructs); (2) Sample consists of healthy adults (male, mean age 21.35, N=76 analyzed) within the 18–65 range; (3) The paper reports group-level voxelwise analyses and describes exploratory whole-brain results beyond ROI analyses (with reference to whole-brain results reported in the manuscript/supplement); (4) Whole-brain results are acceptable to be in supplementary materials per criteria. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes healthy adult task activation maps). Therefore INCLUDE.

studies.title: Interpretation of Social Interactions: Functional Imaging of Cognitive-Semiotic Categories During Naturalistic Viewing.
studies.abstract: Social interactions arise from patterns of communicative signs, whose perception and interpretation require a multitude of cognitive functions. The semiotic framework of Peirce's Universal Categories (UCs) laid ground for a novel cognitive-semiotic typology of social interactions. During functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), 16 volunteers watched a movie narrative encompassing verbal and non-verbal social interactions. Three types of non-verbal interactions were coded ("unresolved," "non-habitual," and "habitual") based on a typology reflecting Peirce's UCs. As expected, the auditory cortex responded to verbal interactions, but non-verbal interactions modulated temporal areas as well. Conceivably, when speech was lacking, ambiguous visual information (unresolved interactions) primed auditory processing in contrast to learned behavioral patterns (habitual interactions). The latter recruited a parahippocampal-occipital network supporting conceptual processing and associative memory retrieval. Requesting semiotic contextualization, non-habitual interactions activated visuo-spatial and contextual rule-learning areas such as the temporo-parietal junction and right lateral prefrontal cortex. In summary, the cognitive-semiotic typology reflected distinct sensory and association networks underlying the interpretation of observed non-verbal social interactions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where 16 volunteers viewed and processed verbal and non-verbal social interactions, fulfilling I1. The abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone; include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=16, ages 22–34) that used a social-related task (viewing and coding social interactions in a 20-min movie) and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (FWE-corrected maps, cluster tables, ROI supplementary analyses, and coordinate tables/figures). Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria for task, sample, and whole-brain reporting (I3, I4, I5, I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Motivation Modulates Brain Networks in Response to Faces Varying in Race and Status: A Multivariate Approach.
studies.abstract: Previous behavioral and neuroimaging work indicates that individuals who are externally motivated to respond without racial prejudice tend not to spontaneously regulate their prejudice and prefer to focus on nonracial attributes when evaluating others. This fMRI multivariate analysis used partial least squares analysis to examine the distributed neural processing of race and a relevant but ostensibly nonracial attribute (i.e., socioeconomic status) as a function of the perceiver's external motivation. Sixty-one white male participants (
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where participants evaluated faces varying by race and socioeconomic status (social perception/understanding of others). Sample comprises 61 adult (white male) participants, indicating healthy adult group. Meets criteria I1 and I2 based on abstract information.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (impression formation of faces varying by race and status) in healthy adult participants (N=60 males, mean age 23.8). The task is clearly social (impression formation), satisfying I3. The sample comprises healthy adults within 18–65, satisfying I4. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise multivariate PLS results (brain–behavior LVs) and displays/thresholds whole-brain voxel maps and cluster reports; GLM preprocessing and contrast images were used as input for PLS, providing group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps, satisfying I5 and I6. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state/seed-only, between-group-only, outside age range, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Hierarchical Brain Network for Face and Voice Integration of Emotion Expression.
studies.abstract: The brain has separate specialized computational units to process faces and voices located in occipital and temporal cortices. However, humans seamlessly integrate signals from the faces and voices of others for optimal social interaction. How are emotional expressions, when delivered by different sensory modalities (faces and voices), integrated in the brain? In this study, we characterized the brains' response to faces, voices, and combined face-voice information (congruent, incongruent), which varied in expression (neutral, fearful). Using a whole-brain approach, we found that only the right posterior superior temporal sulcus (rpSTS) responded more to bimodal stimuli than to face or voice alone but only when the stimuli contained emotional expression. Face- and voice-selective regions of interest, extracted from independent functional localizers, similarly revealed multisensory integration in the face-selective rpSTS only; further, this was the only face-selective region that also responded significantly to voices. Dynamic causal modeling revealed that the rpSTS receives unidirectional information from the face-selective fusiform face area, and voice-selective temporal voice area, with emotional expression affecting the connection strength. Our study promotes a hierarchical model of face and voice integration, with convergence in the rpSTS, and that such integration depends on the (emotional) salience of the stimuli.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI study of brain responses to faces, voices, and combined emotional expressions—clearly a social perception/understanding of others task. The abstract does not state participant health status or ages (18–65), so include for full-text review to confirm I2.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=24, mean age 26) examining neural integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions — a social-perception/communication task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts with FWE-corrected results and MNI coordinates (e.g., rpSTS) in the text/tables and figures. Independent localizers and whole-brain analyses are presented for the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for task relevance, sample, and whole-brain reporting.

studies.title: Age-related differences in the activation of the mentalizing- and reward-related brain regions during the learning of others' true trustworthiness.
studies.abstract: Behavioral studies suggest that older adults may be less adept than younger adults at remembering information contradicting their first impressions about others' trustworthiness. To identify the neural bases associated with such age-related differences, we measured the brain activity of older and younger participants using functional magnetic resonance imaging while they processed feedback on whether their initial trustworthiness impressions of stimulus persons, whose true trustworthiness had been predetermined, were right or wrong. Of special interest was the activation in mentalizing- (e.g., medial prefrontal cortex) and reward-related brain regions (e.g., striatum), which are known to be involved in impression formation and feedback learning, respectively. The reduction in the striatal responses to impression-contradicting versus impression-confirming feedback was greater in older than in younger participants. The activation of some mentalizing-related regions (medial prefrontal cortex and precuneus) was lower in older than younger participants; however, it was not modulated by impression-feedback congruency. The results suggest that age-related differences in the striatum engagement may underlie older adults' inefficiency in learning impression-incongruent information about others' trustworthiness.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (learning others' trustworthiness) involving healthy younger and older participants. It meets I1 (social-related task during fMRI) and appears to meet I2 (includes a healthy younger adult group likely within 18–65). No exclusion criteria apply.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (face-based trustworthiness judgments and feedback learning), satisfying the social-task requirement. It reports task-evoked, group-level voxelwise analyses and whole-brain ANOVA results (tables/figures and Supplementary Table 2), meeting whole-brain reporting standards. The sample includes a healthy younger adult group (ages 20–33) reported separately, satisfying the healthy adult (18–65) sample criterion despite also including older adults. Whole-brain results are clearly described in the text and tables. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply.

studies.title: Role-Specific Brain Activations in Leaders and Followers During Joint Action.
studies.abstract: Much of social interaction in human life requires that individuals perform different roles during joint actions, the most basic distinction being that between a leader and a follower. A number of neuroimaging studies have examined the brain networks for leading and following, but none have examined what effect prior expertise at these roles has on brain activations during joint motor tasks. Couple dancers (e.g., dancers of Tango, Salsa, and swing) are an ideal population in which examine such effects, since leaders and followers of partnered dances have similar overall levels of motor expertise at dancing, but can differ strikingly in their role-specific skill sets. To explore role-specific expertise effects on brain activations for the first time, we recruited nine skilled leaders and nine skilled followers of couple dances for a functional magnetic resonance imaging study. We employed a two-person scanning arrangement that allowed a more naturalistic interaction between two individuals. The dancers interacted physically with an experimenter standing next to the bore of the magnet so as to permit bimanual partnered movements. Together, they alternated between leading and following the joint movements. The results demonstrated that the brain activations during the acts of leading and following were enhanced by prior expertise at being a leader or follower, and that activity in task-specific brain areas tended to be positively correlated with the level of expertise at the corresponding role. These findings provide preliminary evidence that training at one role of a joint motor task can selectively enhance role-related brain activations.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: The study used fMRI during joint leader–follower interactions (a social-related task) and recruited healthy skilled dancers (adult participants), meeting the review’s focus on social processing in healthy adults. Abstract indicates task-based fMRI and healthy subject groups, so it should be included for full-text review to confirm ages and health details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of interactive joint-action (leading vs following) that probes social cognitive processes (mentalizing, perception of others) during a social task. Participants are healthy adults (n=18, mean ages ~40) within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Leading>Following, Following>Leading, conjunctions) with Talairach coordinates and figures, and whole-brain regression analyses; results are presented for the healthy participant group. Therefore it meets all listed inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: The Social Brain Automatically Predicts Others' Future Mental States.
studies.abstract: Social life requires people to predict the future: people must anticipate others' thoughts, feelings, and actions to interact with them successfully. The theory of predictive coding suggests that the social brain may meet this need by automatically predicting others' social futures. If so, when representing others' current mental state, the brain should already start representing their future states. To test this hypothesis, we used fMRI to measure female and male human participants' neural representations of mental states. Representational similarity analysis revealed that neural patterns associated with mental states currently under consideration resembled patterns of likely future states more so than patterns of unlikely future states. This effect manifested in activity across the social brain network and in medial prefrontal cortex in particular. Repetition suppression analysis also supported the social predictive coding hypothesis: considering mental states presented in predictable sequences reduced activity in the precuneus relative to unpredictable sequences. In addition to demonstrating that the brain makes automatic predictions of others' social futures, the results also demonstrate that the brain leverages a 3D representational space to make these predictions. Proximity between mental states on the psychological dimensions of rationality, social impact, and valence explained much of the association between state-specific neural pattern similarity and state transition likelihood. Together, these findings suggest that the way the brain represents the social present gives people an automatic glimpse of the social future.
studies.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study measuring neural representations of others' mental states—clearly a social-related task (Perception and Understanding of Others). Abstract reports human male and female participants but does not specify ages or explicitly state health status, so include for full-text review to confirm criterion I2 (healthy adults 18–65). No exclusion criteria met from abstract.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults. The task explicitly required participants to infer and rate others' mental states (mentalizing), meeting the social-related task requirement. Participants were healthy adults (imaging N=28 after one exclusion; age range 18–22), satisfying the sample age criterion. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise results (searchlight RSA and voxelwise repetition-suppression analyses) with corrected statistical maps and peak MNI coordinates (e.g., dorsal mPFC, posterior precuneus), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results are presented at the group level for the healthy/control sample. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: MDMA Increases Cooperation and Recruitment of Social Brain Areas When Playing Trustworthy Players in an Iterated Prisoner's Dilemma.
studies.abstract: Social decision-making is fundamental for successful functioning and can be affected in psychiatric illness and by serotoninergic modulation. The Prisoner's Dilemma is the archetypal paradigm to model cooperation and trust. However, the effect of serotonergic enhancement is poorly characterized, and its influence on the effect of variations in opponent behavior unknown. To address this, we conducted a study investigating how the serotonergic enhancer 3,4-methylenedioxy-methamphetamine (MDMA) modulates behavior and its neural correlates during an iterated Prisoner's Dilemma with both trustworthy and untrustworthy opponents. We administered 100 mg MDMA or placebo to 20 male participants in a double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study. While being scanned, participants played repeated rounds with opponents who differed in levels of cooperation. On each round, participants chose to compete or cooperate and were asked to rate their trust in the other player. Cooperation with trustworthy, but not untrustworthy, opponents was enhanced following MDMA but not placebo (respectively: odds ratio = 2.01; 95% CI, 1.42-2.84,
studies.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports fMRI scanning during an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma (a social decision-making task), satisfying I1. The sample (20 male participants) is described but health status and ages are not explicitly stated in the abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone; include for full-text review to confirm participant health/age eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=20 males, ages 21–37) using a social decision-making task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) performed during functional MRI. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level task-evoked contrasts and flexible factorial/one-sample t tests with FWE cluster-corrected maps and tables of activations, clearly describing effects for the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain results.
