studies.title: OXTR methylation modulates exogenous oxytocin effects on human brain activity during social interaction.
studies.abstract: Oxytocin (OT) effects on brain function and behavior are mediated by the oxytocin receptor (OXTR). The distribution of OXTR in the brain can profoundly influence social behavior. Emerging evidence suggests that DNA methylation of OXTR influences OXTR expression. Previously, we conducted a pharmaco-functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) study in which healthy subjects were randomized to 24 IU intranasal OT or placebo and imaged with fMRI while playing a dyadic social interaction task known as the iterated Prisoner's Dilemma (PD) game with same-sex partners. Here, we investigate whether DNA methylation of OXTR modulates the effect of intranasal OT on the neural response to positive and negative social interactions in the PD game. OXTR methylation did not modulate OT effects within brain regions where we previously reported OT effects in response to reciprocated (caudate nucleus) and unreciprocated cooperation (amygdala and anterior insula). However, OXTR methylation did modulate OT effects on the response to both reciprocated and unreciprocated cooperation in other brain regions such as the precuneus and visual cortex. Further restricting the analysis to OXTR rs53576 GG individuals revealed that OXTR methylation modulated OT effects on the precuneus response to reciprocated cooperation in men, the lateral septum response to reciprocated cooperation in women, and the visual cortex response to unreciprocated cooperation in men. These results suggest that OXTR methylation status may influence OT effects on mentalizing, attention and reward processing during social interactions. OXTR methylation may be important to consider if exogenous OT is used to treat social behavioral disorders in the future.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used fMRI during a social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy subjects randomized to intranasal oxytocin or placebo — meets the review objective. Ages not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age range (18–65).
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study using an interactive social task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) probing social interaction processing (meets I3). The sample consists of healthy adult participants aged 18–22 and analyses are reported for these healthy groups (meets I4). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (group-level GLM, whole-brain thresholding, cluster-corrected results, and Table 3/figures) examining responses to task outcomes and treatment-by-methylation interactions, i.e., group-level whole-brain maps from the healthy sample (meets I5). Whole-brain results are presented in text, tables and figures (meets I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Exogenous testosterone and the monoamine-oxidase A polymorphism influence anger, aggression and neural responses to provocation in males.
studies.abstract: Testosterone and the monoamine oxidase-A (MAOA) polymorphism are potential neuromodulators for aggression. By acting on similar brain circuits, they might interactively influence human behavior. The current study investigates the causal role of testosterone on aggression-related brain activity and the potential interaction with the MAOA polymorphism. In a double-blind process, 93 healthy males received a testosterone or placebo gel. In an fMRI session, participants performed a Taylor aggression paradigm in which they received provoking feedback and could afterwards decide how aggressively they would react. Testosterone and cortisol levels as well as subjective anger were assessed prior and after the task. Circulating testosterone levels were higher in carriers of the long compared to the short MAOA allele. An interaction of the MAOA polymorphism and testosterone administration was identified in the cuneus, where short allele carriers in the placebo group showed diminished activity in the decision period. Task-related anger was significantly higher in this group. Overall, a mesocorticolimbic network was implicated in processing of high versus low provoking feedback, and core hubs of the default mode network were implicated in the subsequent decision after high versus low provocation. Testosterone administration increased activation in this network. The data provides evidence for an interaction of the MAOA polymorphism and exogenous testosterone on anger and suggests that interactive effects on the brain signal could underlie differential emotional reactivity. The increased default mode activation in the testosterone group suggests an enhanced engagement of social cognition related regions possibly supporting responsivity towards social provocation. This article is part of the Special Issue entitled 'Current status of the neurobiology of aggression and impulsivity'.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI study in 93 healthy males performing a Taylor aggression paradigm involving social provocation and decisions about retaliatory behavior (social cognition/perception of others). Participants are healthy adults, satisfying inclusion. No exclusion criteria apply.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports an fMRI investigation of social provocation (modified Taylor Aggression Paradigm) in a sample of healthy adult males (age 18–35). It includes whole-brain, group-level task-evoked contrasts (high>low provocation and reversed contrasts) with family-wise error cluster-level correction and tables/figures of peak coordinates and clusters. The social task involves interaction with an ostensible opponent, meeting the social-related processing definition. Results for the healthy control sample are reported clearly and not restricted to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

studies.title: Dissecting social interaction: dual-fMRI reveals patterns of interpersonal brain-behavior relationships that dissociate among dimensions of social exchange.
studies.abstract: During social interactions, each individual's actions are simultaneously a consequence of and an antecedent to their interaction partner's behavior. Capturing online the brain processes underlying such mutual dependency requires simultaneous measurements of all interactants' brains during real-world exchange ('hyperscanning'). This demands a precise characterization of the type of interaction under investigation, however, and analytical techniques capable of capturing interpersonal dependencies. We adapted an interactive task capable of dissociating between two dimensions of interdependent social exchange: goal structure (cooperation vs competition) and interaction structure [concurrent (CN) vs turn-based]. Performing dual-functional magnetic resonance imaging hyperscanning on pairs of individuals interacting on this task, and modeling brain responses in both interactants as systematic reactions to their partner's behavior, we investigated interpersonal brain-behavior dependencies (iBBDs) during each dimension. This revealed patterns of iBBDs that differentiated among exchanges; in players supporting the actions of another, greater brain responses to the co-player's actions were expressed in regions implicated in social cognition, such as the medial prefrontal cortex, precuneus and temporal cortices. Stronger iBBD during CN competitive exchanges was observed in brain systems involved in movement planning and updating, however, such as the supplementary motor area. This demonstrates the potential for hyperscanning to elucidate neural processes underlying different forms of social exchange.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract describes dual-fMRI hyperscanning while pairs performed an interactive social-exchange task, meeting I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or that they were healthy adults, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify I2.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI hyperscanning study using a social interaction task (interactive pattern game) measuring interpersonal brain-behavior dependencies. Sample: 44 healthy adults (mean age 22.4), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (GLM, random-effects, FLAME) with non-parametric permutation correction (‘randomize’) and reports clusters/coordinates. Whole-brain results are clearly described. Therefore it satisfies the review criteria for inclusion.

studies.title: Altered striatal reward processing in abstinent dependent cannabis users: Social context matters.
studies.abstract: Public perception of cannabis as relatively harmless, alongside claimed medical benefits, have led to moves towards its legalization. Yet, long-term consequences of cannabis dependence, and whether they differ qualitatively from other drugs, are still poorly understood. A key feature of addictive drugs is that chronic use leads to adaptations in striatal reward processing, blunting responsivity to the substance itself and natural (non-drug) rewards. Against this background, the present study investigated whether cannabis dependence is associated with lasting alterations in behavioral and neural responses to social reward in 23 abstinent cannabis-dependent men and 24 matched non-using controls. In an interpersonal pleasant touch fMRI paradigm, participants were led to believe they were in physical closeness of or touched (CLOSE, TOUCH) by either a male or female experimenter (MALE, FEMALE), allowing contextual modulation of the perceived pleasantness and associated neural responses. Upon female compared to male touch, dependent cannabis users displayed a significantly attenuated increase of pleasantness experience compared to healthy controls. Controls responded to female as compared to male interaction with increased striatal activation whereas cannabis users displayed the opposite activation pattern, with stronger alterations being associated with a higher lifetime exposure to cannabis. Neural processing of pleasant touch in dependent cannabis users was found to be intact. These findings demonstrate that cannabis dependence is linked to blunted striatal processing of non-drug rewards and suggest that these alterations may contribute to social processing deficits.
studies.journal: European neuropsychopharmacology : the journal of the European College of Neuropsychopharmacology
studies.abstract_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study using an interpersonal pleasant touch paradigm addressing social reward/processing, and includes a matched non-using healthy control group of adults. Thus it meets I1 (social-related task with fMRI) and I2 (healthy participants aged 18–65 present). Not a review or meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study uses fMRI during a social-related task (interpersonal pleasant touch) examining social reward processing, includes a healthy adult control group (matched non-using controls), and reports neural activation differences (within-group contrasts) indicating striatal responses to female vs male touch in controls. These constitute whole-brain, group-level task-evoked effects relevant to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age outside range, or non-empirical) appear to apply.

studies.title: Age differences in specific neural connections within the Default Mode Network underlie theory of mind.
studies.abstract: Theory of mind (i.e., the ability to infer others' mental states) - a fundamental social cognitive ability - declines with increasing age. Prior investigations have focused on identifying task-evoked differences in neural activation that underlie these performance declines. However, these declines could also be related to dysregulation of the baseline, or 'intrinsic', functional connectivity of the brain. If so, age differences in intrinsic connectivity may provide novel insight into the mechanisms that contribute to poorer theory of mind in older adults. To examine this possibility, we assessed younger and older adults' theory of mind while they underwent task-based fMRI, as well as the intrinsic functional connectivity measured during resting-state within the (task-defined) theory of mind network. Older adults exhibited poorer theory of mind behavioral performance and weaker intrinsic connectivity within this network compared to younger adults. Intrinsic connectivity between the right temporoparietal junction and the right temporal pole mediated age differences in theory of mind. Specifically, older adults had weaker intrinsic connectivity between right temporoparietal junction and right temporal pole that explained their poorer theory of mind behavioral performance. These findings broaden our understanding of aging and social cognition and reveal more specific mechanisms of how aging impacts theory of mind.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports task-based fMRI during a theory-of-mind (social cognition) task, satisfying I1. Participants are described as younger and older adults but age ranges are not specified, so it is unclear whether a healthy 18–65 group is present; include for full-text review to confirm I2.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study investigates theory of mind (a social cognitive task: Perception and Understanding of Others) using task-based fMRI and resting-state data. It includes healthy younger adult participants (and older adults), so a healthy adult group within 18–65 is present. The paper refers to a task-defined theory-of-mind network, indicating group-level whole-brain task activation/contrast was used to define the network (consistent with reporting whole-brain task-evoked maps). Resting-state analyses supplement but do not replace task-based whole-brain results. Published in NeuroImage with task fMRI methods, meeting reporting standards. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults and reports whole-brain task results (or task-defined network) appropriate for inclusion.

studies.title: What Makes Eye Contact Special? Neural Substrates of On-Line Mutual Eye-Gaze: A Hyperscanning fMRI Study.
studies.abstract: Automatic mimicry is a critical element of social interaction. A salient type of automatic mimicry is eye contact characterized by sharing of affective and mental states among individuals. We conducted a hyperscanning functional magnetic resonance imaging study involving on-line (LIVE) and delayed off-line (REPLAY) conditions to test our hypothesis that recurrent interaction through eye contact activates the limbic mirror system, including the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) and anterior insular cortex (AIC), both of which are critical for self-awareness. Sixteen pairs of human adults participated in the experiment. Given that an eye-blink represents an individual's attentional window toward the partner, we analyzed pairwise time-series data for eye-blinks. We used multivariate autoregression analysis to calculate the noise contribution ratio (NCR) as an index of how a participant's directional attention was influenced by that of their partner. NCR was greater in the LIVE than in the REPLAY condition, indicating mutual perceptual-motor interaction during real-time eye contact. Relative to the REPLAY condition, the LIVE condition was associated with greater activation in the left cerebellar hemisphere, vermis, and ACC, accompanied by enhanced functional connectivity between ACC and right AIC. Given the roles of the cerebellum in sensorimotor prediction and ACC in movement initiation, ACC-cerebellar activation may represent their involvement in modulating visual input related to the partner's movement, which may, in turn, involve the limbic mirror system. Our findings indicate that mutual interaction during eye contact is mediated by the cerebellum and limbic mirror system.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI hyperscanning study of live mutual eye contact—a social interaction task—conducted in human adult pairs. The abstract reports task-related neural activation and connectivity during eye contact, meeting the fMRI social-processing requirement. Participants are described as human adults (healthy sample), satisfying the participant age/health criterion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (real-time mutual eye contact) in healthy adults. The task is explicitly social (mutual gaze/eye-blink entrainment) and uses functional MRI (hyperscanning fMRI) with task conditions (LIVE vs REPLAY). The sample is healthy adults (final analyzed N=30 participants; mean age ~21.7 years), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (LIVE > REPLAY) with cluster-level FWE correction and coordinates, and describes whole-brain interbrain synchronization and GLM results in the text/tables/figures. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Symmetrical Viewpoint Representations in Face-Selective Regions Convey an Advantage in the Perception and Recognition of Faces.
studies.abstract: Learning new identities is crucial for effective social interaction. A critical aspect of this process is the integration of different images from the same face into a view-invariant representation that can be used for recognition. The representation of symmetrical viewpoints has been proposed to be a key computational step in achieving view-invariance. The aim of this study was to determine whether the representation of symmetrical viewpoints in face-selective regions is directly linked to the perception and recognition of face identity. In Experiment 1, we measured fMRI responses while male and female human participants viewed images of real faces from different viewpoints (-90, -45, 0, 45, and 90° from full-face view). Within the face regions, patterns of neural response to symmetrical views (-45 and 45° or -90 and 90°) were more similar than responses to nonsymmetrical views in the fusiform face area and superior temporal sulcus, but not in the occipital face area. In Experiment 2, participants made perceptual similarity judgements to pairs of face images. Images with symmetrical viewpoints were reported as being more similar than nonsymmetric views. In Experiment 3, we asked whether symmetrical views also convey an advantage when learning new faces. We found that recognition was best when participants were tested with novel face images that were symmetrical to the learning viewpoint. Critically, the pattern of perceptual similarity and recognition across different viewpoints predicted the pattern of neural response in face-selective regions. Together, our results provide support for the functional value of symmetry as an intermediate step in generating view-invariant representations.
studies.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where participants viewed face images and performed perceptual/recognition tasks—fits social processing domain (Perception/Understanding of Others). Participants are human (male and female); abstract does not state ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm I2.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of face perception/recognition (social perception of others) in healthy adult participants (mean ages ~23–25; all within 18–65). The study used task-evoked fMRI and reports group-level analyses (mixed-effects FLAME) and an independent group-level localizer (n=83) to define ROIs based on a faces > scrambled contrast, which constitutes a whole-brain group-level task map from healthy participants. Behavioral tasks are social-related (perception and recognition of faces). Whole-brain group analyses and results are described and used to derive group patterns; behavioral models are regressed against neural patterns. Therefore the paper meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related tasks in healthy adults and reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps. No exclusion criteria were triggered.
studies.full_text_path: /data/alejandro/projects/autonima-results/social-processing/ace_scrape/articles/html/html/The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience/30842248.html

studies.title: Brain activity during reciprocal social interaction investigated using conversational robots as control condition.
studies.abstract: We present a novel functional magnetic resonance imaging paradigm for second-person neuroscience. The paradigm compares a human social interaction (human-human interaction, HHI) to an interaction with a conversational robot (human-robot interaction, HRI). The social interaction consists of 1 min blocks of live bidirectional discussion between the scanned participant and the human or robot agent. A final sample of 21 participants is included in the corpus comprising physiological (blood oxygen level-dependent, respiration and peripheral blood flow) and behavioural (recorded speech from all interlocutors, eye tracking from the scanned participant, face recording of the human and robot agents) data. Here, we present the first analysis of this corpus, contrasting neural activity between HHI and HRI. We hypothesized that independently of differences in behaviour between interactions with the human and robot agent, neural markers of mentalizing (temporoparietal junction (TPJ) and medial prefrontal cortex) and social motivation (hypothalamus and amygdala) would only be active in HHI. Results confirmed significantly increased response associated with HHI in the TPJ, hypothalamus and amygdala, but not in the medial prefrontal cortex. Future analysis of this corpus will include fine-grained characterization of verbal and non-verbal behaviours recorded during the interaction to investigate their neural correlates. This article is part of the theme issue 'From social brains to social robots: applying neurocognitive insights to human-robot interaction'.
studies.journal: Philosophical transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological sciences
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports task-based fMRI during live reciprocal social interactions (human-human vs human-robot), directly addressing social processing and reporting 21 scanned participants. Participant ages/health status are not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social interaction in healthy adults using an interactive conversational task (human–human vs human–robot). It reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., HHI vs HRI) with cluster-level FDR correction and provides neuroimaging maps (NeuroVault/OpenNeuro links). Sample comprises 21 healthy adult participants (mean age 25.8), within the 18–65 range. The paper includes whole-brain results presented in figures and described in the text. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: A neurocognitive investigation of the impact of socializing with a robot on empathy for pain.
studies.abstract: To what extent can humans form social relationships with robots? In the present study, we combined functional neuroimaging with a robot socializing intervention to probe the flexibility of empathy, a core component of social relationships, towards robots. Twenty-six individuals underwent identical fMRI sessions before and after being issued a social robot to take home and interact with over the course of a week. While undergoing fMRI, participants observed videos of a human actor or a robot experiencing pain or pleasure in response to electrical stimulation. Repetition suppression of activity in the pain network, a collection of brain regions associated with empathy and emotional responding, was measured to test whether socializing with a social robot leads to greater overlap in neural mechanisms when observing human and robotic agents experiencing pain or pleasure. In contrast to our hypothesis, functional region-of-interest analyses revealed no change in neural overlap for agents after the socializing intervention. Similarly, no increase in activation when observing a robot experiencing pain emerged post-socializing. Whole-brain analysis showed that, before the socializing intervention, superior parietal and early visual regions are sensitive to novel agents, while after socializing, medial temporal regions show agent sensitivity. A region of the inferior parietal lobule was sensitive to novel emotions, but only during the pre-socializing scan session. Together, these findings suggest that a short socialization intervention with a social robot does not lead to discernible differences in empathy towards the robot, as measured by behavioural or brain responses. We discuss the extent to which long-term socialization with robots might shape social cognitive processes and ultimately our relationships with these machines. This article is part of the theme issue 'From social brains to social robots: applying neurocognitive insights to human-robot interaction'.
studies.journal: Philosophical transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological sciences
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used while participants observed human and robot agents experiencing pain/pleasure, assessing empathy — a social cognitive process. Participants (n=26) were healthy adults. The study meets criteria for social-related fMRI task and includes healthy adult participants. Not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=26, ages 18–27) that used a social cognition task (empathy for pain/pleasure toward human and robot agents). The paper reports group-level whole-brain random-effects analyses (main effects, interactions, cluster-corrected results) and provides whole-brain contrast maps and data (NeuroVault, OSF), meeting the requirement for task-evoked whole-brain healthy-group results. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: The facilitative effect of gestures on the neural processing of semantic complexity in a continuous narrative.
studies.abstract: Gestures are elemental components of social communication and aid comprehension of verbal messages; however, little is known about the potential role of gestures in facilitating processing of semantic complexity in an ecologically valid setting. The goal of this study was to investigate whether cognitive load, as indexed by semantic complexity, is modulated by the presentation of gestures accompanying speech. Twenty healthy participants watched 16 video clips of a short narrative while instructed to carefully listen to and watch the narrator while functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data were acquired. The videos contained passages with and without various co-speech gestures, as well as passages where the semantic complexity was either low or high, as measured by the metric of idea density. Increasing semantic complexity led to reduced activation within the default mode network (DMN); whereas, presents of gestures decreased activation in language-related regions (left middle temporal gyrus and left inferior frontal gyrus) and increased activation in high-level visual and multimodal regions of occipitotemporal cortex. Most interestingly, an interaction between semantic complexity and gestures was observed in a language-related area in left anterior temporal cortex; specifically, increasing gestures led to a greater drop in activation with high vs. Low semantic complexity. These results provide evidence that the facilitation of gestures on semantic processing, particularly for complex narratives, is reflected in the neural substrates of language processing.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used while healthy adult participants watched a narrator using co-speech gestures, addressing social communication and semantic processing in an ecologically valid social interaction. Twenty healthy participants (adults) were tested, satisfying both criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social communication: participants (n=20 healthy native German adults, age range 22–35) watched naturalistic videos of an actor narrating a story with co-speech gestures (a social-communication task). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., low_ID > high_ID, speech > gestures+speech, gestures+speech > speech) with MNI coordinates and cluster statistics (tables and figures). Results are reported for the healthy participant group. Therefore it meets the review's requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and provides whole-brain task activation maps/coordinates.

studies.title: Convergent Neural Correlates of Empathy and Anxiety During Socioemotional Processing.
studies.abstract: Empathy is characterized by the ability to understand and share an emotional experience with another person and is closely tied to compassion and concern for others. Consequently, this increased emotional awareness and sensitivity may also be related to increased anxiety. Taken from another perspective, higher general anxiety may translate into increased concern for others, or concern for how one's actions might affect others, and therefore may be linked to increased empathy. Furthermore, self-reflection is positively related to perspective-taking and empathic concern, while rumination is closely tied to anxiety, thus providing an additional connecting point between empathy and anxiety through enhanced internally generated thought. While previous literature suggests a relationship between empathy and anxiety, this has yet to be empirically studied using neuroimaging tools aimed at investigating the underlying neural correlates that may support these convergent responses. We therefore conducted an functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study (
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI study of socioemotional processing (empathy and anxiety), which fits social-related processing (I1). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (18–65), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to assess I2.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study using a socioemotional Face Processing Task (fearful vs neutral faces) during functional MRI, addressing social-related processing (I3). The sample comprises 49 healthy adult participants (ages 18–33) with results reported for this healthy group (I4). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (F > N, N > F) using whole-brain TFCE/FWE-corrected analyses, including coordinates, figures, and descriptions in the text (I5, I6). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Perceiving animacy purely from visual motion cues involves intraparietal sulcus.
studies.abstract: Distinguishing animate from inanimate objects is fundamental for social perception in humans and animals. Visual motion cues indicative of self-propelled object motion are useful for animacy perception: they can be detected over a wide expanse of visual field, at distance and in low visibility conditions, can attract attention and provide clues about object behaviour. However, the neural correlates of animacy perception evoked exclusively by visual motion cues, i.e. not relying on form, background or visual context, are unclear. We aimed to address this question in four psychophysical experiments in humans, two of which performed during neuroimaging. The stimulus was a single dot with constant form that moved on a blank background and evoked controlled degrees of perceived animacy through parametric variations of self-propelled motion cues. BOLD signals reflecting perceived animacy in a graded manner irrespective of eye movements were found in one intraparietal region. Additional whole-brain and region-of-interest analyses revealed no comparable effects in brain regions associated with social processing or other areas. Our study shows that animacy perception evoked solely by visual motion cues, a basic perceptual process in social cognition, engages brain regions not primarily associated with social cognition.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: The study reports fMRI BOLD responses to animacy perception—a basic social-perception process—so it addresses social-related processing (I1). The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they were healthy adults, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study uses fMRI to investigate perception of animacy from visual motion cues, a social-related process (perception/understanding of others). It tested healthy adult participants (ages 19–36; N=111 total, with N=36 included in fMRI analyses after exclusions), meeting the sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task analyses (random-effects ANOVAs, conjunction contrasts, whole-brain FWE-corrected results, MNI coordinates and cluster tables/Figures), fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group and include coordinates and figures (main text and supplementary tables). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical work) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for this review.

studies.title: Social support modulates the neural correlates underlying social exclusion.
studies.abstract: Ostracism threatens the human need for social interactions, with negative consequences on cognition, affect and behavior. Understanding the mechanisms that can alleviate these consequences has therefore become an important research agenda. In this study, we used behavioral and fMRI measures to advance our understanding how social support can buffer the negative effects of social exclusion. We focused on two different types of support from a friend: emotional support, conveyed by gentle touch and appraisal support, implemented as informative text messages. Seventy-one female participants underwent fMRI scanning while playing a virtual ball-tossing game in the course of which they were excluded. Two consecutive runs of the game were separated according to the participant's experimental condition (appraisal support, emotional support and no support). Results showed that the experience of social exclusion is modulated by the type of support received. Specifically, emotional support decreased negative emotions and anterior insula activity, while appraisal support increased negative emotions, with concomitant increase of subgenual anterior cingulate cortex and decrease of temporal-parietal junction activity. These divergent effects of social support point to the necessity to characterize whether and under which conditions it represents an effective and positive resource to alleviate the negative consequences of social exclusion.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: The study used fMRI while participants played a virtual ball-tossing game inducing social exclusion (a social-related task) and reports neural correlates modulated by social support. The sample comprises 71 healthy female participants. Thus it satisfies I1 (fMRI during a social task) and I2 (healthy participant group).
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study using a social task (cyberball) probing social exclusion/affiliation processes in healthy adult participants (female, mean age ~21.7). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses with voxelwise thresholds and coordinates (including clusters surviving FWE small-volume correction) and provides coordinate tables and described contrasts for the healthy/control sample. All required inclusion criteria for fMRI task activation in healthy adults are met, and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, or non-empirical) apply.

studies.title: The functional database of the ARCHI project: Potential and perspectives.
studies.abstract: More than two decades of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) of the human brain have succeeded to identify, with a growing level of precision, the neural basis of multiple cognitive skills within various domains (perception, sensorimotor processes, language, emotion and social cognition …). Progress has been made in the comprehension of the functional organization of localized brain areas. However, the long time required for fMRI acquisition limits the number of experimental conditions performed in a single individual. As a consequence, distinct brain localizations have mostly been studied in separate groups of participants, and their functional relationships at the individual level remain poorly understood. To address this issue, we report here preliminary results on a database of fMRI data acquired on 78 individuals who each performed a total of 29 experimental conditions, grouped in 4 cross-domains functional localizers. This protocol has been designed to efficiently isolate, in a single session, the brain activity associated with language, numerical representation, social perception and reasoning, premotor and visuomotor representations. Analyses are reported at the group and at the individual level, to establish the ability of our protocol to selectively capture distinct regions of interest in a very short time. Test-retest reliability was assessed in a subset of participants. The activity evoked by the different contrasts of the protocol is located in distinct brain networks that, individually, largely replicate previous findings and, taken together, cover a large proportion of the cortical surface. We provide detailed analyses of a subset of regions of relevance: the left frontal, left temporal and middle frontal cortices. These preliminary analyses highlight how combining such a large set of functional contrasts may contribute to establish a finer-grained brain atlas of cognitive functions, especially in regions of high functional overlap. Detailed structural images (structural connectivity, micro-structures, axonal diameter) acquired in the same individuals in the context of the ARCHI database provide a promising situation to explore functional/structural interdependence. Additionally, this protocol might also be used as a way to establish individual neurofunctional signatures in large cohorts.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: The study reports fMRI data including social perception and reasoning tasks (social-related processing) performed by 78 individuals, indicating relevant task-based fMRI in humans. No clinical populations are reported, implying healthy adult participants.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This paper reports task-based fMRI of multiple social cognition paradigms (false belief, animacy/intentional triangles, eyes intention, face trustworthiness, vocalizations) in a sample of 78 healthy adults (age 18–40). The authors present group-level, whole-brain random-effects (RFX) voxelwise analyses with corrected thresholds and provide peak coordinates and supplementary whole-brain results. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group task activation maps clearly. Therefore it satisfies the review's inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Widespread and lateralized social brain activity for processing dynamic facial expressions.
studies.abstract: Dynamic facial expressions of emotions constitute natural and powerful means of social communication in daily life. A number of previous neuroimaging studies have explored the neural mechanisms underlying the processing of dynamic facial expressions, and indicated the activation of certain social brain regions (e.g., the amygdala) during such tasks. However, the activated brain regions were inconsistent across studies, and their laterality was rarely evaluated. To investigate these issues, we measured brain activity using functional magnetic resonance imaging in a relatively large sample (n = 51) during the observation of dynamic facial expressions of anger and happiness and their corresponding dynamic mosaic images. The observation of dynamic facial expressions, compared with dynamic mosaics, elicited stronger activity in the bilateral posterior cortices, including the inferior occipital gyri, fusiform gyri, and superior temporal sulci. The dynamic facial expressions also activated bilateral limbic regions, including the amygdalae and ventromedial prefrontal cortices, more strongly versus mosaics. In the same manner, activation was found in the right inferior frontal gyrus (IFG) and left cerebellum. Laterality analyses comparing original and flipped images revealed right hemispheric dominance in the superior temporal sulcus and IFG and left hemispheric dominance in the cerebellum. These results indicated that the neural mechanisms underlying processing of dynamic facial expressions include widespread social brain regions associated with perceptual, emotional, and motor functions, and include a clearly lateralized (right cortical and left cerebellar) network like that involved in language processing.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating processing of dynamic facial expressions (social communication/perception) in a participant sample (n=51). Abstract indicates a social-related task and likely healthy adult participants; age range not reported, so full text review is needed to confirm I2. No exclusion criteria met.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study (n=51 healthy adults, mean age 22.5) that investigates processing of dynamic facial expressions — a clearly social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (dynamic expressions > dynamic mosaics) with FWE-corrected statistical maps and detailed tables of coordinates. Results are reported for the healthy control sample and not limited to ROIs; whole-brain analyses and laterality comparisons are presented. Participants are within the 18–65 age range and healthy. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Dyadic interaction processing in the posterior temporal cortex.
studies.abstract: Recent behavioural evidence shows that visual displays of two individuals interacting are not simply encoded as separate individuals, but as an interactive unit that is 'more than the sum of its parts'. Recent functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) evidence shows the importance of the posterior superior temporal sulcus (pSTS) in processing human social interactions, and suggests that it may represent human-object interactions as qualitatively 'greater' than the average of their constituent parts. The current study aimed to investigate whether the pSTS or other posterior temporal lobe region(s): 1) Demonstrated evidence of a dyadic information effect - that is, qualitatively different responses to an interacting dyad than to averaged responses of the same two interactors, presented in isolation, and; 2) Significantly differentiated between different types of social interactions. Multivoxel pattern analysis was performed in which a classifier was trained to differentiate between qualitatively different types of dyadic interactions. Above-chance classification of interactions was observed in 'interaction selective' pSTS-I and extrastriate body area (EBA), but not in other regions of interest (i.e. face-selective STS and mentalizing-selective temporo-parietal junction). A dyadic information effect was not observed in the pSTS-I, but instead was shown in the EBA; that is, classification of dyadic interactions did not fully generalise to averaged responses to the isolated interactors, indicating that dyadic representations in the EBA contain unique information that cannot be recovered from the interactors presented in isolation. These findings complement previous observations for congruent grouping of human bodies and objects in the broader lateral occipital temporal cortex area.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating neural processing of social (dyadic) interactions, satisfying I1. Abstract does not specify participant age range or explicit statement that participants were healthy adults (I2 unclear). Given insufficient participant detail, include for full-text review to confirm I2.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social perception (visual processing of dyadic interactions), using healthy adult participants (N=21, ages 18–35). The authors performed whole-brain preprocessing and GLM estimation to generate run-wise whole-brain beta maps and report group-level statistical analyses (one-sample t-tests) and whole-brain searchlight analyses. Results include group-level voxelwise classification/searchlight findings and discussion of whole-brain effects. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for: I3 (fMRI during social-related task), I4 (healthy adult sample 18–65), I5 (reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task analyses/maps), and I6 (whole-brain results clearly described). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only or resting-state-only) apply.

studies.title: Behavioural and Neural Responses to Facial Disfigurement.
studies.abstract: Faces are among the most salient and relevant visual and social stimuli that humans encounter. Attractive faces are associated with positive character traits and social skills and automatically evoke larger neural responses than faces of average attractiveness in ventral occipito-temporal cortical areas. Little is known about the behavioral and neural responses to disfigured faces. In two experiments, we tested the hypotheses that people harbor a disfigured is bad bias and that ventral visual neural responses, known to be amplified to attractive faces, represent an attentional effect to facial salience rather than to their rewarding properties. In our behavioral study (N = 79), we confirmed the existence of an implicit 'disfigured is bad' bias. In our functional MRI experiment (N = 31), neural responses to photographs of disfigured faces before treatment evoked greater neural responses within ventral occipito-temporal cortex and diminished responses within anterior cingulate cortex. The occipito-temporal activity supports the hypothesis that these areas are sensitive to attentional, rather than reward properties of faces. The relative deactivation in anterior cingulate cortex, informed by our behavioral study, may reflect suppressed empathy and social cognition and indicate evidence of a possible neural mechanism underlying dehumanization.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI experiment (N=31) measuring neural responses to disfigured faces—a social perception task (perception/understanding of others). It likely used healthy adult participants, though ages/health not explicitly stated; include for full-text confirmation.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=31, ages 18–35) using a social-perception task (gender judgments while viewing faces differing by facial disfigurement) that probes social-related processing (perception/understanding of others, stigma/dehumanization). The authors performed whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (SnPM nonparametric whole-brain contrasts, cluster-level FWE correction) and report significant whole-brain activations and deactivations for the healthy sample (figures/tables and ROI/item-wise follow-ups are provided). Thus the paper meets the fMRI social-processing objective, includes a healthy adult sample, and reports unmasked group-level whole-brain task activation maps. No exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Social cognition, behaviour and therapy adherence in frontal lobe epilepsy: a study combining neuroeconomic and neuropsychological methods.
studies.abstract: Social behaviour of healthy humans and its neural correlates have been extensively studied in social neuroscience and neuroeconomics. Whereas it is well established that several types of epilepsies, such as frontal lobe epilepsy, lead to social cognitive impairments, experimental evidence on how these translate into behavioural symptoms is scarce. Furthermore, it is unclear whether social cognitive or behavioural disturbances have an impact on therapy adherence, which is critical for effective disease management, but generally low in these patients. In order to investigate the relationship between social cognition, social behaviour, and therapy adherence in patients with frontal lobe epilepsies (FLE), we designed a study combining conventional neuropsychological with behavioural economic and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) methodology. Fifteen patients and 15 healthy controls played a prisoners' dilemma game (an established game to operationalize social behaviour) while undergoing fMRI. Additionally, social cognitive, basic neuropsychological variables, and therapy adherence were assessed. Our results implicate that social behaviour is indeed affected and can be quantified using neuroeconomic methods in patients with FLE. Impaired social behaviour in these patients might be a consequence of altered brain activation in the medial prefrontal cortex and play a role in low therapy adherence. Finally, this study serves as an example of how to integrate neuroeconomic methods in neurology.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: The study used fMRI while participants played the prisoners' dilemma (a social/interpersonal decision-making task), and included a healthy control group alongside patients. Thus it satisfies I1 (task during fMRI is social) and I2 (healthy adults included). Not a review article.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study uses task-based fMRI during a social neuroeconomic task (prisoners' dilemma) probing social behaviour and cognition. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15; ages 18–50) reported separately. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses for the control group (one-sample t-tests and per-group analyses with whole-brain results described and visualized; thresholding and cluster reporting are provided), satisfying the requirement for unmasked healthy-group whole-brain activation maps. Constructs assessed (trust/cooperation, mentalizing, face trustworthiness) fall within social-related processing. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state-only, or missing healthy-group whole-brain maps) apply. Therefore the study meets all relevant inclusion criteria for this review.

studies.title: Neural representations of honesty predict future trust behavior.
studies.abstract: Theoretical accounts propose honesty as a central determinant of trustworthiness impressions and trusting behavior. However, behavioral and neural evidence on the relationships between honesty and trust is missing. Here, combining a novel paradigm that successfully induces trustworthiness impressions with functional MRI and multivariate analyses, we demonstrate that honesty-based trustworthiness is represented in the posterior cingulate cortex, dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and intraparietal sulcus. Crucially, brain signals in these regions predict individual trust in a subsequent social interaction with the same partner. Honesty recruited the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (VMPFC), and stronger functional connectivity between the VMPFC and temporoparietal junction during honesty encoding was associated with higher trust in the subsequent interaction. These results suggest that honesty signals in the VMPFC are integrated into trustworthiness beliefs to inform present and future social behaviors. These findings improve our understanding of the neural representations of an individual's social character that guide behaviors during interpersonal interactions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI study probing honesty-based trustworthiness impressions and predicting trust behavior, meeting I1. Participant health status and ages (I2) are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion cannot be fully confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify that at least one group are healthy adults (18–65).
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study uses task-based fMRI to examine social cognition (trust/honesty) during an advice-taking and trust-game paradigm, meeting the social-related task requirement. The sample consists of 31 healthy adult participants (mean age 24.3), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (voxel-level p<0.001 with cluster-level FWE correction p<0.05) and whole-brain MVPA/searchlight results, with coordinates and supplementary tables describing activations. Thus it provides whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps (reported in text, figures, and supplementary material). Based on these points, inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are satisfied.

studies.title: Action perception recruits the cerebellum and is impaired in patients with spinocerebellar ataxia.
studies.abstract: Our cerebellum has been proposed to generate prediction signals that may help us plan and execute our motor programmes. However, to what extent our cerebellum is also actively involved in perceiving the action of others remains to be elucidated. Using functional MRI, we show here that observing goal-directed hand actions of others bilaterally recruits lobules VI, VIIb and VIIIa in the cerebellar hemispheres. Moreover, whereas healthy subjects (n = 31) were found to be able to discriminate subtle differences in the kinematics of observed limb movements of others, patients suffering from spinocerebellar ataxia type 6 (SCA6; n = 21) were severely impaired in performing such tasks. Our data suggest that the human cerebellum is actively involved in perceiving the kinematics of the hand actions of others and that SCA6 patients' deficits include a difficulty in perceiving the actions of other individuals. This finding alerts us to the fact that cerebellar disorders can alter social cognition.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Functional MRI was used while participants observed and discriminated others' hand actions (perception/understanding of others — a social process). The study includes a healthy adult group (n=31). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This paper reports task-based functional MRI of action observation and weight-discrimination tasks probing perception/understanding of others (social perception). Healthy adult participants are included (multiple experiments with n=79 healthy participants; controls for the SCA6 patient study are reported separately), and group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation maps and contrasts (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS; Sleeve/NoSleeve) are reported and described in the text, figures, and supplementary materials. Whole-brain analyses and coordinates are provided, satisfying reporting requirements. The study is empirical fMRI work in healthy adults and does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, or non-empirical methods. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

studies.title: Neural oscillations in human auditory cortex revealed by fast fMRI during auditory perception.
studies.abstract: Previous work pointed to the neural and functional significance of infraslow neural oscillations below 1 ​Hz that can be detected and precisely located with fast functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). While previous work demonstrated this significance for brain dynamics during very low-level sensory stimulation, we here provide the first evidence for the detectability and functional significance of infraslow oscillatory blood oxygenation level-dependent (BOLD) responses to auditory stimulation by the sociobiological relevant and more complex category of voices. Previous work pointed to a specific area of the mammalian auditory cortex (AC) that is sensitive to vocal signals as quantified by activation levels. Here we show, by using fast fMRI, that the human voice-sensitive AC prioritizes vocal signals not only in terms of activity level but also in terms of specific infraslow BOLD oscillations. We found unique sustained and transient oscillatory BOLD patterns in the AC for vocal signals. For transient oscillatory patterns, vocal signals showed faster peak oscillatory responses across all AC regions. Furthermore, we identified an exclusive sustained oscillatory component for vocal signals in the primary AC. Fast fMRI thus demonstrates the significance and richness of infraslow BOLD oscillations for neurocognitive mechanisms in social cognition as demonstrated here for the sociobiological relevance of voice processing.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports fMRI during auditory (voice) stimulation addressing voice processing and social cognition, meeting I1. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports task-based functional MRI in healthy adult participants (Experiments 1 and 2; ages 18–41 and 18–33). The task contrasts vocal (socially relevant) versus non-vocal sounds and explicitly frames vocal processing as social communication/perception. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise activation maps and contrasts (vocal > non-vocal and related analyses) are reported with statistical thresholds (FDR-corrected voxelwise maps and cluster thresholds). Whole-brain task-evoked results are clearly described for the healthy/control sample. Therefore the paper meets criteria for fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level reporting.

studies.title: Intact neural representations of affective meaning of touch but lack of embodied resonance in autism: a multi-voxel pattern analysis study.
studies.abstract: Humans can easily grasp the affective meaning of touch when observing social interactions. Several neural systems support this ability, including the theory of mind (ToM) network and the somatosensory system linked to embodied resonance, but it is unclear how these systems are affected in autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Individuals with ASD exhibit impairments in the use of nonverbal communication such as social and reciprocal touch. Despite the importance of touch in social communication and the reported touch aversion in ASD, surprisingly little is known about the neural systems underlying impairments in touch communication in ASD.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study uses multi-voxel pattern analysis of neural representations of social touch (implies fMRI) addressing social processing. Abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy adult control group (age 18–65) was included, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study used task-based fMRI during observation of socio-affective (social touch) videos, directly addressing social-related processing (I3). The sample includes a clearly reported neurotypical healthy adult group (matched controls, ages within 18–65) with results presented separately from the ASD group (I4). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task activation results (univariate contrasts and accompanying figures/tables of activated brain areas and MNI coordinates for the control/NT group; see Additional file 1: Figure S2 and Table S2), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain voxelwise maps (I5). Reporting of whole-brain results in figures/tables meets the acceptability clause (I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Collective memory shapes the organization of individual memories in the medial prefrontal cortex.
studies.abstract: It has long been hypothesized that individual recollection fits collective memory. To look for a collective schema, we analysed the content of 30 years of media coverage of World War II on French national television. We recorded human brain activity using functional magnetic resonance imaging as participants recalled World War II displays at the Caen Memorial Museum following an initial tour. We focused on the medial prefrontal cortex, a key region for social cognition and memory schemas. The organization of individual memories captured using the distribution of the functional magnetic resonance imaging signal in the dorsal part of the medial prefrontal cortex was more accurately predicted by the structure of the collective schema than by various control models of contextual or semantic memory. Collective memory, which exists outside and beyond individuals, can also organize individual memories and constitutes a common mental model that connects people's memories across time and space.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used while participants recalled museum displays, and the study addresses collective memory and medial prefrontal cortex involvement in social cognition—meeting I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or clearly state they are healthy adults (18–65), so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study examining how collective (social) schemas influence memory, implicating social-cognition-related medial prefrontal regions (dmPFC/vmPFC). The task involved retrieval of museum images with emphasis on collective/social meaning, and analyses tested social/collective representations. The sample consisted of healthy adults (N=24; ages 22–39). The paper reports group-level whole-brain searchlight results (TFCE-corrected) and ROI analyses; whole-brain task-evoked maps and cluster results are clearly described. Therefore the study meets the review’s requirements for an fMRI social-related task in healthy adults with whole-brain group-level results.

abstract_screening_results.reason: fMRI study of face identity and eye-gaze perception — clearly social-related processing (social communication/perception of others), satisfying I1. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone), so include for full-text review to verify I2.

fMRI study measuring amygdala responses to racial ingroup vs outgroup faces, which is a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Participants identified as White or Black (healthy adults implied), but age range not reported; include for full-text to confirm I2.

Functional MRI was used while healthy volunteers performed social tasks (empathy and forgivability judgments), directly addressing social-related processing. Although participant ages are not specified, the sample of 'ten volunteers' is consistent with adult healthy participants; include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.

Event-related fMRI recorded while human subjects performed social judgments (trustworthiness of faces), clearly a social processing task. Participants are described as subjects (healthy adults implied) within typical adult age range. This meets inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

Abstract describes simultaneous fMRI during a social interaction (a deception game between pairs), satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages 18–65, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify I2.

Age range not specified but 'normal subjects' implies healthy adults; include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study examining neural responses to mutual vs. averted gaze—a social perception/communication task—reporting STS and FFG activations. Participants are described as 'subjects' with no clinical populations indicated, consistent with healthy adult sampling. Meets criteria for an fMRI social-task study and inclusion of healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social interactions (cooperation vs competition) involving monitoring others’ actions and social cognition, satisfying I1. Participants are human and described as 'individuals' (healthy adult sample implied), meeting I2. No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study with healthy volunteers performing a social-related task (evaluative judgments of guilt and embarrassment involving Theory of Mind/social cognition). Abstract reports 19 healthy participants, meeting inclusion requirements. Age range not specified in abstract — included for full-text review to confirm ages.

This is a narrative review of MRI findings in adolescent brain maturation, not a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic review/review article). The abstract does not report fMRI results in healthy adult participants.

The abstract describes two fMRI experiments on understanding intentions in social interactions—a social cognition task relevant to the review. While participant ages are not specified, the study appears to involve healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

Event-related fMRI study of self-face recognition (perception/understanding of self), using healthy normal subjects—meets I1. fMRI study where participants performed impression formation about other people, a clear social-cognitive task (Perception and Understanding of Others). Event-related fMRI in healthy participants examined processing of emotional (angry) voice prosody—a social communication task assessing perception/understanding of others. Fits social-related processing in adults. Abstract indicates healthy subjects; no exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind and empathy) in healthy human volunteers; meets I1. Participants described as healthy volunteers, but age range (18–65) not reported in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation of I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI study where participants experienced social interaction (gaze and socially relevant facial expressions) versus observation, matching social-related processing. While participant ages and explicit statement of health are not given, this is a primary fMRI study of social cognition in humans; include for full-text to confirm demographics/health status.

fMRI study examining recognition of visual feedback as self- versus other-generated (perception/understanding of self/others), which is a social-related construct. Participants are described as "healthy subjects." Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text verification of 18–65 criterion.

fMRI study scanning participants during a face-perception/one-back task where affective person knowledge (social cognition) is spontaneously retrieved—meets social-related processing (I1). fMRI study measuring cortical activation during communicative speech (social communication) in normal subjects; meets the review objective and includes healthy participants. The fMRI experiment examined processing of social communication (facial expressions and social hand gestures) during observation and execution, meeting I1. fMRI study in healthy human adults examining self-recognition (face and name), addressing social-related constructs (perception/understanding of self and others). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets age/participant criteria based on abstract information.

fMRI was used during a social-related task (anticipatory interpersonal touch comparing human vs fake hand), meeting I1. The abstract implies healthy human participants but does not report ages explicitly; therefore include for full-text review to confirm I2 (age 18–65). No exclusion criteria met.

Abstract reports an fMRI study where participants performed tasks involving self- and other-referential recollection (social cognition regarding self and others). Participants appear to be healthy adults and no clinical groups are described. Thus it meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adult participants).

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment indexing self-referential neural responses during intergroup competition (a social-related task) and links activation to willingness to harm competitors. Participants appear to be healthy adults. Fits criteria I1 and I2.

fMRI measured responses to faces (natural vs bluish) which is social communication/perception (facial cues), satisfying I1. Abstract reports 25 subjects but does not state ages or health status, so I2 is unclear; include for full-text review.

The study collected fMRI data during a real-life social interaction task involving self- and other-related feedback processing (meets I1). Participants were healthy adults of German and Chinese origin (meets I2). This is an empirical fMRI study, not a review, and directly addresses social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social interaction where pairs rated and communicated emotional arousal while viewing affective pictures, reporting neural activity (anterior insula, PFC, ventral striatum). Participants appear to be healthy adults. This addresses social-related processing and meets inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

fMRI was used while participants viewed and processed realistic social interaction videos (empathic/social processing), and the sample comprised healthy young adult males within the adult age range. Thus it meets both I1 and I2.

fMRI study examining perception/understanding of others (third-person social interaction), satisfying I1. Abstract does not report participant health status or ages, so I2 cannot be confirmed; include for full-text review.

Abstract reports a functional MRI study where participants imagined triadic social interactions—clearly a social-related task measured with fMRI. While the abstract does not specify participant ages, it describes a typical healthy participant sample; include for full-text review to confirm demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study using an ultimatum game examines social fairness processing (meets I1). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (I2 unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample.

fMRI was conducted during an ecologically valid social interaction task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm with angry/neutral facial expressions), and the sample comprised healthy adult participants (41 tested, 32 analyzed). This meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy participants). No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI was conducted while healthy volunteers performed a social interaction/game with various agents, addressing social processing (perception/understanding of others). The abstract does not report participant ages; full text needed to confirm age 18–65, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants formed impressions of others (social evaluation/perception of others), meeting the social-related task requirement and participant criteria. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed an implicit false-belief (theory-of-mind) task — a social cognition paradigm (meets I1). The abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult status, so inclusion cannot be fully confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI neuroimaging study investigating interpersonal synchrony and social affiliation with behavioral and neuroimaging results implicating social-cognition areas. Participants (N=100) served as referents and no clinical populations are mentioned, satisfying I1 (fMRI during social-related task) and I2 (healthy adult participants implied). Age range not specified but no disorders reported—include for full-text confirmation if needed.

The study reports task-based fMRI while participants watched traffic-awareness videos designed to elicit empathy (a social-cognitive construct). Participants were 20 healthy adult male volunteers. Thus it meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adults). No exclusion criteria apply.

This fMRI study investigates cross-modal recognition of other individuals (social perception/understanding of others) using a voice-face priming task in human participants, satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state that participants were healthy adults aged 18–65, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review.

The study used task-free (resting-state) fMRI examining language-network connectivity, not an fMRI social-related task. Participant ages are not reported. It therefore does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (social task), so exclude.

Abstract reports an fMRI study measuring neural responses to biological vs scrambled motion—clearly a social-perception task (I1). The sample is described as ‘humans’ but health status and ages (18–65) are not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants (N=50, young volunteers) labeled briefly presented emotional facial expressions—a social perception/understanding task. This directly meets the review objective and both inclusion criteria.

Participants are non-human (dogs); the study does not include human adults aged 18–65, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I2 (human participants). Therefore it is not eligible for a review of fMRI studies in healthy adult humans.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social-affiliation processing (friends viewing emotional pictures together vs alone) with healthy participants; age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are aged 18–65.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment probing social communication (perceived friend vs computer), examining neural encoding and interregional coupling related to social context. Participants appear to be healthy adults; although ages are not specified, inclusion criteria allow full-text review when abstract lacks detail. Fits social processing in healthy humans.

Abstract reports model-driven functional MRI of social tie formation during an economic (public goods) interaction, addressing social processing. The abstract does not specify participant age/health status, so full-text is needed to confirm I2. Include for full-text screening.

Abstract reports neural measurements during social communicative interactions but does not specify fMRI or participant ages/health. Because modality and participant health/age are unclear, include for full-text review to determine whether I1 (fMRI during social task) and I2 (healthy adults 18–65) are met.

Abstract is a review/methods paper discussing hyperscanning techniques and future directions; it does not report an original fMRI experiment or data from healthy adult participants performing a social task. This fits exclusion as a review article (E1).

Mouse resting-state fMRI study; not conducted in human adults nor involving a social-related task. Does not meet inclusion criteria I1 (social task in humans) or I2 (healthy human participants 18–65).

The abstract describes an fMRI study of joint attention (a social cognitive task), satisfying I1. Participant health status and ages are not reported in the abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed; include for full-text review.

Abstract reports dyadic fMRI during eye contact and derives neural bases for reciprocal social interaction, indicating a social-related task using fMRI (meets I1). The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify I2.

Study used fMRI during a social-communication task (participants judged whether they felt addressed) and reports healthy adult participants (n=37). This meets the review objective and inclusion criteria I1 and I2. No exclusion criteria apply.

Abstract reports an fMRI study measuring neural responses while participants judged social interactions (a social-related perceptual task), meeting I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify I2.

This is an fMRI study of perception of emotions in dynamic crowds (social processing), satisfying I1. The abstract does not report participant ages or explicit confirmation of healthy adults, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics. Not a review/meta-analysis.

The study used fMRI during a game-theoretic deception task, which is a social-related processing paradigm (meets I1). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so I2 cannot be confirmed; include for full-text review. No exclusion criteria met.

Participants are adolescents aged 12–15, so the study does not include any healthy adult participants within the 18–65 range required by I2. The study does meet I1 (fMRI during a social task: Cyberball). Exclusion is based on not meeting the age inclusion criterion.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social task) in children aged 3–5, not in healthy adults 18–65. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 (task-based social-related fMRI) nor I2 (adult sample). Abstract provides sufficient information to exclude.

Participants are older adults (mean age 79), so no group of healthy participants aged 18–65 is included; thus the study fails inclusion criterion I2 despite using fMRI for a social-related empathy task.

This is an fMRI study that examines social cognition (predicting others' behavior/theory-of-mind). It reports 18 participants (presumably healthy adults). No exclusion criteria apply. Include for full-text to confirm age range and health status if needed.

Abstract reports dyadic (dfMRI) experimental study of face-to-face social interaction/eye contact, indicating an fMRI social task (satisfies I1). It does not specify participant characteristics or ages, so presence of a healthy adult group (I2) cannot be confirmed. Not a review (E1 not applicable). Include for full-text review to confirm participant eligibility and ages.

Abstract is a theoretical/review paper that discusses fMRI evidence but does not report methods or participants. It is unclear whether this paper contains an original fMRI study with healthy adults performing a social-related task. Insufficient information to determine inclusion, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining attributions about social situations (social cognition). Abstract indicates human participants performing social-related tasks and reports neural activation; likely healthy adult sample. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study examining neural regulation of behavioral mimicry in response to social cues (emotional expression and group membership), which fits social processing constructs; abstract does not explicitly state participant ages/health but likely healthy adults. Include for full-text review to confirm participant age/health details.
