No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply.

This study reports task-evoked BOLD fMRI during a social cognition task (facial emotion recognition vs age discrimination), in a sample of healthy adults aged 20–35 (n=29). The paper provides group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (FWE-corrected maps and tables of MNI coordinates) for explicit and implicit conditions and direct contrasts, clearly reported for the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study reports an fMRI experiment that manipulates self-referential processing and perspective taking (social cognitive tasks), recruiting healthy adult participants and reporting group-level task-evoked activations across medial prefrontal cortex. The full-text describes specific whole-brain activation results (ventral/dorsal anterior MPFC, posterior dorsal MPFC, left dorsal MPFC) from contrasts comparing self vs. other and perspective-taking conditions, indicating voxelwise group-level results. Thus it meets the review objective (social processing in healthy adults) and provides whole-brain task activation evidence.

The study reports task-based fMRI of social communication (communicative speech production vs description), involving healthy adult participants (n=29, ages 18–24). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise random-effects analyses and contrasts are reported (communication vs description; communication vs control; familiar vs unfamiliar), with cluster-corrected thresholds and tables of coordinates. Results for the healthy control group are clearly presented. Therefore it meets the review objective and satisfies whole-brain reporting requirements.

The study employed task-based fMRI probing social interaction/friendship (affiliation/attachment), fulfilling the social-related task requirement. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=28, age range 19–27), satisfying the healthy adult sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects ANOVA) with familywise error correction and provides tables/figures of activations and coordinates clearly derived from the healthy/control group. Whole-brain results are described in text, figures, and Table 1. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (I3, I4, I5, I6) and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study used fMRI during an emotional facial-expression paradigm (implicit and explicit processing), which is a social-related task addressing social communication and perception of others. The sample is described as 12 healthy subjects (adult sample implied), and the abstract reports group-level BOLD signal increases across multiple brain regions (thalamus, hippocampus, frontal gyri, caudate, cingulum, occipital regions, etc.), indicating whole-brain task-evoked results reported in the text. Thus the study meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI (I3), a healthy adult sample (I4; ages not specified in provided excerpt but participants are described as healthy subjects), and reporting of whole-brain group-level activations consistent with I5 and acceptable reporting format per I6. No exclusion criteria from the provided list are clearly violated. Confidence is moderate due to lack of explicit age range in the provided excerpt and lack of access to full PDF to confirm exact reporting format and coordinate tables.

This study used task-based fMRI to examine how observers evaluate whether an actor’s actions are consistent with another’s intentions (social cognition). Participants were healthy adults (final N=16, ages 18–29). The paper reports voxelwise whole-brain analyses (voxelwise ANOVAs and thresholded activation maps) and identifies group-level activation/deactivation in multiple brain regions (DLPFC, posterior STS, medial prefrontal/precuneus, lingual gyrus, somatosensory cortex), not limited to ROI results. Results are reported for the healthy/control group. The design is task-evoked (animated social interactions), not resting-state or connectivity-only, and is empirical. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

The study reports task-based fMRI (event-related fMRI) during perception of others’ emotional facial expressions, a social-processing task (empathy/face perception). Participants were 14 healthy adult volunteers (mean age 29±6), meeting the adult sample criterion. The authors used Statistical Parametric Mapping and report activation in dorsal medial frontal cortex (pre-SMA) during emotion perception, indicating group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results described in the text. Results are presented as whole-brain activation (SPM), satisfying acceptable reporting formats. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample) apply. Therefore all inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 are met.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults investigating social communication (viewing, imitating, producing facial expressions and social hand gestures). The abstract reports group-level activation loci and condition differences (e.g., IPL and frontal operculum showing differential activation), indicating whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results/contrast maps rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. The sample is described as typical participants (healthy adults) and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) appear to apply based on the available full-text information. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3 (fMRI social-related task), I4 (healthy adult sample), I5 (group-level whole-brain task-evoked results), and I6 (results clearly reported).

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind: cooperation, deception) in healthy adults (n=13; ages 22–38), meeting the review’s population requirement. The task explicitly assesses social-related processing (intentions/beliefs), satisfying I3. Whole-brain group analyses are reported (exploratory whole-brain ToM vs non-ToM; second-level paired t-tests and contrasts are described with reported coordinates and thresholds), meeting I5 and I6. The sample is within the 18–65 range, meeting I4. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy-group whole-brain task effects, and is empirical, so no exclusion criteria apply. Inclusion criteria applied: ["I3","I4","I5","I6"].

This is an fMRI study of social hierarchical processing in healthy adults. The experiments used task-based fMRI with social interactions (social hierarchy task) relevant to social perception/understanding of others. Sample includes healthy adult participants (24 per social experiment; ages 19–43, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses (SPM5) with thresholded statistical maps and tables of coordinates for contrasts such as ‘superior player > inferior player’ and outcome contrasts; results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. Whole-brain results appear in text, figures, and tables (FDR-corrected maps and coordinate tables). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of reflective social processing that uses task-based whole-brain BOLD analyses (referential processing and social attribution tasks). Participants are healthy adults (17 analyzed; mean age 21.5, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise results (composite t-maps, FDR-corrected maps) with coordinates and tables of peak activations, and figures showing whole-brain maps, satisfying reporting requirements. Therefore it meets the review’s task, sample, and whole-brain reporting criteria.

This is an fMRI study of a social interactive task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult participants (Experiments with mean ages ~20–21, both sexes included in Experiment 2). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (PD vs Gamble) with tables of activation coordinates and figures, and describes random-effects analyses and thresholding. Whole-brain results are clearly reported for the healthy/control sample (not restricted to a narrow subgroup). Therefore it satisfies: I3 (fMRI social task), I4 (healthy adult sample), I5 (group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps), and I6 (results reported in tables/figures and text).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (age 18–24) that investigates self- and other-related processing (self-face and self-name recognition), a social-cognition task relevant to perception/understanding of self and others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses using SPM5 with statistical thresholds and tables of peak coordinates and cluster results, clearly from the healthy/control group. Thus it meets the meta-analysis requirements for task domain, sample, and whole-brain reporting.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=26, mean ages ~24) using an empathy/ emotional perspective-taking paradigm (SELF and OTHER tasks), which is directly social-related processing. Group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses are reported (simple effects of SELF- and OTHER-tasks versus a high-level baseline) with tables of peak coordinates and whole-brain FWE-corrected results and SPMs described. Results for the healthy control sample are presented separately and not limited to an ROI-only approach. Therefore the paper satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social tasks in healthy adults and provides whole-brain task activation maps/tables suitable for meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing using a social motor response (ball-tossing) task that manipulates social inclusion/exclusion and models temporal-difference signals. The sample comprises 18 healthy adults (mean age 42±12), within the 18–65 range, with results reported for the healthy group. Group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (SPM2 one-group t tests) are reported, with FDR whole-brain correction (P<0.05) and coordinates/tables/figures provided. The study therefore meets the review objectives and satisfies all required inclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adults (n=17, ages 20–34) that explicitly investigates social communication (gaze following and finger pointing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (each condition vs. baseline and subtraction contrasts), with statistical maps and coordinates described and ROI analyses secondary. Results for the healthy adult group are reported clearly and separately. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults with whole-brain results.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants that explicitly investigates social-related processing (perception/recognition of self vs others’ body parts using own/other hand images). The methods describe task-based fMRI and report group-level voxelwise contrasts/cluster coordinates (e.g., body vs objects localizer, LOC and V1/2 clusters with Talairach coordinates and voxel counts), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results (reported as coordinates/cluster info). Although the primary analyses use ROIs and fMR-adaptation, the paper also reports whole-brain contrasts and coordinates rather than ROI-only results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy or non-adult samples) are violated. Therefore the study meets the review inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=12 included; ages 21–31) that directly investigates social-related processing (attribution of intentions/mental states to perceived human vs computer-generated musical pieces). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (Composer > Computer) with coordinates and cluster-corrected statistics in tables/figures. All required inclusion criteria are met (I3–I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study (task-based BOLD) investigating theory-of-mind/social-exchange versus precautionary reasoning using the Wason selection task. Participants were healthy adults (n=12 analyzed, mean age 24.6). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses and contrasts (story and card phases), with voxelwise thresholds and reported clusters/tables, satisfying whole-brain reporting. Thus it meets the meta-analysis objective of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults and satisfies the listed inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related auditory task (listening to one vs. two walkers) engaging social cognition and affect-related processes. Participants were healthy adults (n=12; ages 22–37). Group-level whole-brain random-effects analyses are reported with voxelwise contrasts, statistical maps, figures, and Talairach coordinates describing activations (e.g., STEP1+STEP2 – REST, STEP2 – NOISE2), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Results for the healthy/control group are presented (not limited to a subgroup). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not outside age range, empirical with original fMRI data).

The study reports original task-based fMRI data in healthy adult participants (17 right-handed males, mean age 25.9) who viewed socially relevant facial expressions, satisfying the review objective. Analyses are whole-brain, voxelwise FIR/GLM random-effects analyses (SPM5) with reported statistical maps and stereotactic coordinates, and condition-specific contrasts are described. The task paradigms probe social communication and perception/understanding of others. There is clear healthy-group reporting separate from any clinical subgroup. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are met. Therefore the paper meets inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI task study of social interaction in healthy adults (N=17, mean age 26). The task manipulates social vs. individual actions and gaze, clearly a social-related paradigm. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (main effects and interaction) with peak coordinates, statistical thresholds (p<.001 uncorrected) and tables/figures describing activation (e.g., dMPFC, IFG, pSTS, amygdala). Results are reported for the healthy participant group; no ROI-only or connectivity-only limitations apply. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social perception (approach with happy vs angry expressions) in healthy adults (young adults, N=10). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise contrasts (Angry > Happy and Happy > Angry) with MNI coordinates and a summary table of activated clusters, clearly attributed to the healthy participant group. Results are not limited to ROIs, are not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and include whole-brain task activation maps described in the text and tables. Therefore it meets the review’s fMRI social-task and whole-brain reporting requirements.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (20 right-handed participants, age 20–34) investigating neural responses to observed actions and effects of sensorimotor training. The task probes perception/understanding of others’ actions (a social-related construct). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (conjunctions and contrasts) with correction for multiple comparisons and provides peak coordinates and tables (Table 1) and figures, clearly identified for the healthy/control group. Thus all required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition: participants made social judgments (vegetable-preference mentalizing and age categorization) while undergoing whole-brain EPI fMRI. Sample: 18 healthy adult undergraduates (mean age 20), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts with Talairach coordinates and cluster tables (task main effects and social-group main effects), clearly from the healthy/control group. Results are not limited to ROI, connectivity, or non-task analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study investigating social processing (gaze shifts) using a task that manipulates social context and goal-directedness. Participants were healthy adults (behavioral: n=10, fMRI: n=12; ages 18–40), and analyses used whole-brain, voxelwise SPM second-level (random-effects) contrasts with reported activation maps and tables of coordinates for task effects (e.g., ‘gaze shift - no movement’, ‘incorrect - correct’, ‘social - unsocial’). Whole-brain group-level results are clearly reported for the healthy sample. Therefore all inclusion criteria for task-based fMRI in healthy adults are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study that uses a social-related task (face target detection within an oddball paradigm) and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (FSL mixed-effects, cluster-corrected maps and MNI coordinates). The sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=19; age range 19.3–47.5), and results for the healthy group are reported. Whole-brain results are presented in figures and tables of coordinates. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of others’ pupil dynamics/social salience) in healthy adults (N=14, mean age 22). The experiment used task-based fMRI with reported group-level whole-brain analyses (main effect of viewing eyes reported at whole-brain corrected cluster threshold; effects of pupil change reported with voxelwise thresholds and region-of-interest analyses). Results are clearly presented as healthy-group task-evoked activation maps in the text, figures, and coordinates. All inclusion criteria (I3, I4, I5, I6) are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of self-processing (a social-related construct: Perception and Understanding of Self) in healthy adult participants (24 right-handed university students, ages ~21–24). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise random-effects analyses and provides coordinate tables and figures for multiple contrasts (e.g., main effects and interaction contrasts) from the healthy sample. Results are presented as whole-brain maps (tables of coordinates and corrected ROI results), satisfying the requirement that whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps are reported. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy age group-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This study used task-based fMRI during an explicit emotion-recognition paradigm (social communication/perception of others). The sample comprised healthy adult males aged 21–33. The paper reports group-level whole-brain (whole-slab) analyses with activation maps and voxelwise results (thresholded maps and reported MNI coordinates for parahippocampal and inferior frontal gyrus findings), alongside ROI analyses. Therefore it provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from the healthy group and meets the review’s requirements.

This is an fMRI study of empathy/perspective-taking (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (n=23, ages 19–34). The experiment uses task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm, reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Pain > No Pain, No Pain: Dissimilar > Similar) with thresholding and cluster tables/figures, and provides coordinate tables and figures. Whole-brain task activation maps and contrasts for the healthy sample are clearly reported alongside behavioral measures. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none.

This study used task-based fMRI to investigate mental state decoding (Reading the Mind in the Eyes), a social-perceptual task relevant to social communication and perception/understanding of others. Participants were healthy adults (native Japanese and white American, ages 18–27) and analyzed separately. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., RME - gender discrimination) with voxelwise results, tables of activated regions/coordinates, conjunctions, and corrected thresholds, clearly identifying healthy-group effects. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social decision-making (Trust Game) in healthy adult participants (ages 18–22). The task probes social cognition/reciprocity (perception/understanding of others, affiliation/reciprocity). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and provides tables of MNI coordinates and statistical maps (Table 1, whole-brain and ROI results). Healthy adult sample is reported separately (n=18 for fMRI analyses). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, not outside age range, and is empirical).

This is an fMRI study of attachment/affiliation (social processing) in healthy adults. The sample comprises 51 healthy right-handed adults aged 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., masked sad vs neutral; tables of coordinates and figures) clearly from the healthy sample. Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task activation reporting.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (ages 24–37; N=10 for fMRI) using socially relevant non-verbal vocalizations and animated faces, addressing social-related perception/understanding of others. Group-level voxelwise statistical analyses (voxel-by-voxel two-tailed t tests, maps transformed to Talairach space, thresholded maps and ROI analyses) are presented as group activation maps (figures/tables), satisfying group whole-brain voxelwise reporting (not merely ROI-based). Healthy adult results are reported separately and clearly. Although slice coverage was focused on temporal cortex, the paper presents group voxelwise task-evoked activation maps and contrasts for the healthy sample, meeting the review’s requirements.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=26, mean age 24.4) that explicitly investigates social-contextual modulation of perception of others' pain (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., pain > no pain; social context contrasts; interaction contrasts) with tables of coordinates and FDR-corrected thresholds, along with figures and ROI/PPI analyses. Thus it meets the fMRI social-task requirement, includes a healthy adult sample within 18–65, and provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps/results (reported in tables/figures/text). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study should be included.

While the study clearly meets the review’s scope (healthy adult sample, social-related fMRI task involving audiovisual integration of non-verbal emotional communication), its analyses are based on an ROI-based approach of individually mapped STS measuring points. The authors extracted parameter estimates from spherical ROIs along the STS and performed one-sample t-tests on these ROI values. The report does not present an unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map or whole-brain statistical maps/tables for the healthy group; results are limited to the ROI-based statistics and peak-normalized contrast estimates. Therefore it violates the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise results and meets exclusion criterion E2 (ROI-only analyses with no whole-brain results).

This study reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (direct and reflected self-appraisals, perspective-taking; relevant to perception/understanding of self and others). It includes a healthy adult group (N=12, ages 22.6–30.4) reported separately. The authors report unmasked, whole-brain group-level task analyses (contrasts and conjunctions) corrected across the whole brain and present adult within-group activation results (tables/figures and text). Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind) using a naturalistic video-based task (MASC) in healthy adult participants (n=18, ages 20–45). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., ToM vs. physical inference) with cluster-level thresholding and provides coordinates and tables of activations (Table 1) and figures. Whole-brain GLM results and model-free T-PICA spatial maps are presented and described for the healthy sample. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group results. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study uses task-based fMRI while participants view stigmatized vs control faces (a social cognition task), satisfying I3. The sample includes healthy young and older adults; young adults fall within the 18–65 range, satisfying I4. The abstract reports group-level neural activity (e.g., greater medial prefrontal cortex activity in young adults; lateral PFC activity in older adults), indicating voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked results reported for the healthy groups, satisfying I5. Reporting of activations in text/figures/tables meets I6. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only without healthy-group maps, out-of-range ages only, or non-empirical) are evident. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study investigating empathy and social cognition in healthy adults (n=16 analyzed, mean age 27.8). Participants performed a picture-viewing task probing social/empathic processing (emotional vs. neutral; one vs. two persons). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses, statistical maps (FDR threshold), and a table of Talairach peak coordinates for task contrasts (e.g., Emotional > Neutral; Social relation > Single person). Results for the healthy/control sample are reported directly. Therefore the study meets the review inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI tasks, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked results.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self and other trait judgments) in healthy adults (final N=13). The task involves social cognition constructs (perception/understanding of self and others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (SPM contrasts) with tables of coordinates and figures, demonstrating task-evoked activation maps from the healthy participant group. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social joint-attention task (participants view an avatar looking at occluded bodies or places), satisfying the social-processing objective. Sample comprises healthy adults (ages 20-31; data from 12 participants analyzed). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses and provides whole-brain contrast maps and a table of coordinates for body>place and place>body contrasts (Table 1, figures), fulfilling whole-brain evidence requirements. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 and violates no exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study investigates charitable donation decisions (a social cognition task involving empathy, perspective-taking, and valuation), tested in 22 healthy adult participants (ages 19–38). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps (VMPFC, pSTC, anterior insula) with corrected thresholds and coordinate-based results and includes tables and figures of whole-brain contrasts. Therefore it satisfies the social-related task requirement, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study investigating social processes (live face-to-face interaction and joint attention) in healthy adults. Participants were healthy adults (ages 18–29) and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Live > Recorded; Joint Attention > Solo Attention) with coordinates and corrected thresholds. Whole-brain results are presented in tables and figures. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria I3 (fMRI social task), I4 (healthy adult sample 18–65), I5 (whole-brain group-level task activation maps), and I6 (coordinates/figures clearly described). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) are met.

This is an fMRI study of prosody perception and production tied to social communication and empathy (social-related processing). Sample: 19 healthy, right-handed native-English adults aged 18–58 (within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., “happy-neutral”, “question-neutral”) thresholded and corrected (p<0.05 FDR, cluster k>5) and describes coordinates and supplementary materials; overlap/SVC and whole-brain contrasts are reported in text and figures. Results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. No evidence of ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range samples. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study investigating social expectancy violations (social/person-perception constructs), using a task-based paradigm with healthy adult participants (Princeton undergraduates, mean age 20.4). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task activation analyses with Talairach coordinates and statistical thresholds (p<.001) and ROI follow-ups; results are clearly from the healthy/control group. Whole-brain results are presented in tables/figures and described in text. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI empirical study of empathy/attachment (social-related processing) in healthy adults. It uses functional MRI during a social task (imagining self, loved-one, stranger in painful vs neutral scenarios) addressing affiliation/attachment and self/other perception. The sample is healthy adults (N=36, mean age 23), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Pain vs Neutral; Self vs Stranger; Loved-one vs Stranger) with statistical thresholds (FDR-corrected) and provides stereotactic coordinates and tables/figures of results (main effects and contrasts), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain evidence. Results for the healthy group are presented directly. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range sample) apply. Therefore it meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study that used a social-related task (socio-emotional preference task assessing ‘Do I like this person?’) with healthy adult participants (n=21; ages 23–51). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (Preference > Gender and other contrasts) analyzed with SPM2 and thresholded at p<0.05 FDR, with tables of stereotactic coordinates and whole-brain statistical maps described in the text and figures. Although the paper also includes PPI connectivity analyses, it additionally provides unmasked whole-brain activation results for the healthy control group. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study with healthy adult participants (ages 19–31) that used a social-related task assessing recognition of personally familiar versus famous faces (a social cognition task involving perception and understanding of others and social attachment). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., P1-Cp1, P1-F1) and provides statistical maps and tables using SPM5 with cluster correction. All inclusion criteria (I3, I4, I5, I6) are met; no exclusion criteria apply.

This paper reports an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (heterosexual male undergraduates, age range within 18–65) using a social cognition task (passive viewing of sexualized and clothed human targets—perception and understanding of others/mentalizing). The manuscript presents group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (exploratory whole-brain deviant-cell contrast thresholded at p<.001 with cluster correction via AlphaSim) and tables/figures of the results, and reports correlations between hostile sexism and whole-brain activity. Thus it satisfies the review's requirements for an fMRI task study in healthy adults with whole-brain results.

This study used fMRI during a social communication task (charades) involving healthy adult participants (18 analyzed; mean age 27.5). The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses (differential Granger-causality maps and GLM results) thresholded and described at the group level, with figures and supplementary information documenting voxelwise effects. Thus it meets the review's requirements for a social-related fMRI task in healthy adults and provides whole-brain task-evoked results. No exclusion criteria are violated.

The study investigates social processing (dynamic facial expressions) in healthy adult participants using fMRI. However, the reported analyses rely primarily on ROI-based small-volume-corrected voxelwise results (WFU PickAtlas masks, SVC) and do not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map clearly attributed to the healthy/control group. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain evidence (I5) and falls under Exclusion criterion E2 (ROI-only results).

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing/inferring others’ preferences) in healthy adults (n=64, ages 18–26). The task is explicitly social (perception/understanding of others), satisfying I3. Participants are healthy adults within 18–65, satisfying I4. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses with voxelwise results and peak coordinates (Table 1) and figures displaying MPFC activations, meeting I5 and I6. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all required inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=23, ages 21–37) that investigates social gaze effects on action control — a social-related construct (social communication/perception of others). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (SPM second-level ANOVA, main effects and interactions), thresholding and cluster tables/figures with coordinates and anatomical localization, and brain–behavior correlations. Thus it meets all inclusion requirements: use of task-based fMRI for social processing (I3), healthy adult sample reported separately (I4), and whole-brain group-level task-evoked maps reported in text/tables/figures (I5,I6). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, not between-group-only, participants are within 18–65, and this is empirical fMRI data).

Although this fMRI study used a social task (Cyberball) and included a healthy adult group (16 adults, age range ~24–39), the paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map that is clearly identified as coming from the healthy adult group alone. The authors report whole-brain contrasts across the combined adolescent+adult sample and report an interaction (and SVC/peak-based post-hoc tests) and small-volume–corrected results for predicted regions, plus regionwise post-hoc t-tests in adults, but do not present an adult-only whole-brain, voxelwise task map (exclusion>inclusion) for the healthy adult group. Therefore it fails criterion I5 and meets exclusion criterion E4 (only between-group/interaction/SVC/ROI/post-hoc results without an accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect). Inclusion criteria met: I3 (fMRI during social-related task), I4 (healthy adult participants present), I6 (whole-brain results acceptable in format). Exclusion criterion applied: E4.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social cognition (judgments about self, friends, and strangers) in healthy adults (n=98; mean age 20.7). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., self > other, friends > strangers) with whole-brain maps and thresholding (p<0.001 uncorrected) and ROI analyses; whole-brain results are clearly attributed to the healthy/control participants. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria for an fMRI social-related task in healthy adults and reports whole-brain group-level activation results.

This paper reports an fMRI task probing social processes (empathy/sympathy) using validated social stimuli (meets I3). The sample includes healthy adult participants within the 18–65 range (ages up to 40) alongside children/adolescents (meets I4). The manuscript presents group-level, whole-brain task activation maps/contrasts (PCS–NPS and PCO–PCS) and random-effects analyses with voxelwise results and coordinates (meets I5). Whole-brain results are reported in figures, tables, and text (meets I6). Although the sample is mixed-age rather than adult-only, healthy adults are included and whole-brain task-evoked maps from the healthy participant group are provided. Therefore the study satisfies the inclusion criteria for the review.

The study reports fMRI of adolescents (three phases of adolescence) performing the Trust Game and describes developmental changes across adolescent age groups. The sample appears to consist of adolescent participants only, with no healthy adult group (age 18–65) reported separately. Therefore it fails the sample inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group. Additionally, the abstract does not confirm reporting of adult whole-brain group maps. Exclusion applied because participants fall outside the 18–65 range with no eligible adult subgroup reported.

The study used task-based fMRI to investigate face individuation, which falls under social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). The sample consists of healthy adults (mean age 24.8), meeting the age and health requirements. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation analyses (voxelwise ANOVA and corrected cluster-threshold whole-brain results described in the Supplementary Material and main text), not limited to ROI-only findings. Whole-brain results are clearly described and reported in figures/tables. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6, and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

This study used task-based fMRI to investigate perception and understanding of social interactions via point-light displays (social vs non-social conditions). Participants were 14 healthy adults (mean age 29.4), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise analyses (SI > NSI contrast) with FDR correction and cluster reporting, clearly from the healthy sample. Results are reported in text, figures, and tables of activations. All required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of humor processing—a social-cognitive domain involving perception/appraisal and theory-of-mind processes—conducted in healthy adults (N=29, mean age 27). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (Cartoons vs. Neutral) and parametric modulation analyses with FWE and Monte-Carlo cluster corrections, and provides peak coordinates/tables and conjunctions for the healthy participants. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes clearly reported whole-brain activation maps for the healthy control group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social cognition (perception/understanding of others) using an impression-formation task contrasting stereotypically congruent vs incongruent social targets. The sample comprises healthy adults aged 19–30 (n=18 after exclusions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (incongruent > congruent) with results surviving FDR correction and a table of MNI coordinates and figures illustrating activations (MPFC, bilateral TPJ, etc.). Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level task activation reporting.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction/episodic memory in healthy adults (n=24, age 18–28). The task explicitly manipulates social vs. non-social context and self vs. other generation (social-related processing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts and cluster-corrected results (tables and figures with MNI coordinates) identifying activations (e.g., right and left mPFC). Healthy adult results are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult volunteers (N=20) who viewed dynamic social interaction videos (positive and negative), addressing social-related processing. The abstract and results describe group-level whole-brain activation with voxelwise findings (right>left activation in amygdala, IFG, fusiform, temporal gyri; p<0.0001), which constitutes a healthy-group, whole-brain task effect rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participants are described as young adults (within 18–65). Therefore the paper meets inclusion criteria I3 (social-related fMRI task), I4 (healthy adult sample), I5 (group-level whole-brain task activation), and I6 (results reported in acceptable formats). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) appear to apply.

This is an fMRI study investigating allocentric social hierarchy and social alliance judgements (social cognition). Participants: 22 healthy right-handed adult males (mean age 24.2, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level whole-brain random-effects analyses (SPM2 second-level), with results reported as voxelwise contrasts, p<0.05 FWE corrected, and coordinate tables/figures for the healthy group. Tasks are social-related (hierarchy/alliance) and meet the review constructs. No exclusion criteria (ROIs-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages, or absence of whole-brain healthy-group maps) apply. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an empirical fMRI study of prosocial decisions (mentalizing/self-control) toward family — a social processing task. Sample: 25 healthy young adults (Mage=20.2), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (Costly-Donation vs Noncostly-Reward) with tables of coordinates and whole-brain regression and PPI results; whole-brain results are clearly described and thresholded (FDR-corrected) and reported in tables/figures. Thus it meets the task, sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements.

This empirical fMRI study investigates perception/understanding of the self (self-face recognition) using task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (ages 19–24). It reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (SPM) and lists significant activations (e.g., MPFC, PCC, precuneus) from within-group contrasts (Morph 50% self vs friend; Morph 100% vs 60%), meeting whole-brain reporting thresholds. Sample consists of healthy adults and results are reported for the healthy group. Therefore it satisfies the review objective and all required inclusion criteria.

The study uses task-based fMRI during observation of virtual social interactions (meets I3). Participants are described as recruited by age/health with results reported from 15 participants, consistent with a healthy adult sample (meets I4). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain activation maps and figures showing task-evoked activations (STS, mPFC, amygdala) based on the full sample, indicating whole-brain voxelwise results for the healthy group (meets I5). Results are reported in figures and described in text, which is acceptable (meets I6). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, age outside range, or non-empirical) appear to apply.

This is an fMRI study investigating how eye contact modulates mimicry, a social cognitive process. The sample comprises 20 healthy adult participants (mean age 23), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Direct > Averted, Incongruent > Congruent, interaction contrasts) with results summarized in Table 1 and figures, satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Thus it meets the review objective of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (N=20, mean age 18.7) using a social-comparison task (romantic partner vs roommate). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise second-level SPM contrasts (e.g., Target × Breadth interaction, Positive>Negative, Close>Non-Close) with peak coordinates and corrected statistics (FWE-corrected within a priori ROIs and reported cluster coordinates), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain group task-evoked results. Behavioral and imaging methods are described for a healthy adult sample and results are reported for the healthy group. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=20) using a block design with dynamic face, voice, and bimodal face-voice conditions addressing cross-modal face-voice integration—a social-perception construct relevant to social communication/person perception. The abstract reports voxelwise group-level results using multiple statistical criteria (super-additive, max, mean) identifying brain regions (e.g., left hippocampus) and discusses whole-brain effects; PPI connectivity is reported in addition to task activation. Thus the paper provides whole-brain, group-level task-evoked maps for a healthy adult sample and meets inclusion requirements.

This is an empirical fMRI study that directly contrasts social (stereotype) and non-social semantic judgments. Participants were healthy adults (ages 19–28). The authors report whole-brain, random-effects (voxelwise) group-level contrasts (e.g., social > non-social; non-social > social) with corrected thresholds and accompanying tables/figures. Reporting of whole-brain results in text, figures and tables satisfies the reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, not between-group-only, participants within 18–65, empirical data present).

This is an fMRI study of audiovisual emotion perception—a social communication/social cognition task—using healthy adult participants (n=24, ages 18–34). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM analyses with voxelwise maps, conjunctions, and thresholding (FDR), and presents whole-brain results in figures and tables of coordinates. Thus it meets the review objective and inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This paper reports an original fMRI task manipulating social interaction (human vs. machine opponent) during a Stroop competition paradigm, directly targeting Theory of Mind / perception-and-understanding-of-others. Participants were healthy adults (mean age 35.9, n=14), and results are reported from random-effects, whole-brain group-level voxelwise analyses with contrasts and tables of activation peaks/coordinates. The manuscript provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps reported as cluster results and coordinate tables for main effects and interactions (e.g., I(H+M) > C(H+M), H(I+C) > M(I+C), interactions). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets the review’s fMRI and healthy adult whole-brain reporting requirements and is eligible for inclusion.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (Cyberball social exclusion), targeting social processing. Sample: healthy adults (n=20 after exclusions), ages within 18–65. The paper provides group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (social exclusion > fair play and same- vs other-gender exclusion), with voxelwise results reported in tables and figures and cluster-level correction, satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain results are clearly present. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This empirical fMRI study used a social-task (ultimatum game) to probe social decision-making and reports both ROI-based online analyses and whole-brain, cross-subject offline classification. Participants were healthy adult males (ages 23–28). The paper describes whole-brain preprocessing, voxelwise feature selection, cross-subject SVM classification, and reports discriminating volumes/voxels with p-values (i.e., group-level whole-brain results presented and discussed). Thus it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and reporting of whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise results. No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of biological motion perception (a social-related task assessing perception/understanding of others). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=13, mean age 28.2, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (canonical vs. scrambled biological motion) thresholded at p<0.05 corrected, with MNI coordinates and tables/figures detailing activations. Thus it meets the fMRI social task requirement, healthy adult sample requirement, and provides whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps. No exclusion criteria apply.

This study reports task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample (n=22, ages 19–35) examining affective (social) touch — a social-related construct mapping onto affiliation/attachment and social perception. Group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM results are reported (arm>baseline, palm>baseline, arm>palm) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster correction; results are presented in tables of peak coordinates and figures. Although PPI connectivity is also reported, the paper clearly includes unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study examined emotional prosody comprehension (including complex social emotions) — a social-cognitive task involving perception and understanding of others’ emotions (social communication/ToM). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=19 males, ages 18–51). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise SPM8 analyses (one-sample t-tests, contrasts such as emotional vs neutral and complex vs simple), with cluster-level correction and activation maps/coordinate reporting. These results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy control group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (team membership/in-group bias) in healthy adult volunteers. The study used task-based fMRI during social-related action-perception and decision tasks, reporting whole-brain, group-level voxelwise contrasts (e.g., single-video vs fixation; paired-judgment vs baseline) with cluster-level FWE correction and peak coordinates. Participants were healthy adults (right-handed Caucasian males; age range 17–43, i.e., predominantly adult sample) and results for the healthy group are reported. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only approaches. Therefore the study satisfies the inclusion criteria for task-based whole-brain fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study that explicitly manipulates social information load (social working memory) during task performance. Participants were healthy adults (n=16, mean age 20) and results report group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses with coordinates and surface-rendered maps showing parametric load effects in canonical and mentalizing networks. The paper provides whole-brain statistical maps/tables and describes group-level effects for the healthy sample. It does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, between-group contrasts, or non-empirical methods. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study of empathic decision-making—a social cognition task involving perception/understanding of others (empathy). Participants: 32 healthy adult males (mean age 22.8), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (multiple GLMs, whole-brain cluster-corrected results, tables of activations and figures). Supplementary data and coordinate tables are provided. Thus the study clearly meets the social-related task requirement, uses fMRI in healthy adults, and provides whole-brain group-level results (reported in main text, tables and figures). No exclusion criteria are met.

The study reports a task-based fMRI experiment in healthy adults (N=20, mean age 22) investigating processing of communicative vs noncommunicative vocal sounds — a social-communication task. Group-level, whole-brain random-effects contrasts are reported (vocal > nonvocal; communicative > noncommunicative) with thresholding and peak coordinates provided in tables and figures. Results for the healthy adult group are presented separately. Therefore it meets the requirement for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults with whole-brain task-evoked maps.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (affiliation vs. isolation) using task-evoked BOLD fMRI. It includes a healthy younger adult group (mean age ~20.8; within 18–65) and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses with tables of peak coordinates and contrasts (conjunctions and between-group contrasts). Results for the healthy groups are clearly reported (within- and between-group contrasts and coordinate tables), and whole-brain maps/analyses are presented in the text/tables. Although the paper also includes an older adult group (>65), the younger healthy adult group meets the sample age criterion and has separable whole-brain results. Therefore the study satisfies the review inclusion criteria for task, sample, and whole-brain reporting.

This empirical fMRI study examines valenced self-referential and other-referential processing (VV-SORP-T), a social cognition task probing perception/understanding of the self and others. Sample: 20 healthy adult women aged 18–52 (within 18–65), with exclusion of psychiatric history — satisfies healthy adult sample requirement. Imaging methods: whole-brain, voxelwise SPM8 analyses are reported (group-level contrasts vs fixation and between-condition contrasts) with voxel-wise thresholds, cluster reports, ROI and whole-brain results presented in figures/tables and described in text. Thus the paper includes unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, non-empirical) are triggered. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an fMRI study that examines social evaluation/impression formation (social-related task) using task-based functional MRI. The sample includes a healthy young adult group (20–29 years), satisfying the 18–65 age criterion; group-level results are reported separately for young and older adults. The paper reports whole-brain, random-effects group analyses with corrected thresholds and presents conjunction and contrast results (tables/figures) for the healthy groups, fulfilling whole-brain reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age-out-of-range-only, non-empirical) are violated. Therefore all inclusion criteria relevant to this review are met.

This is an fMRI study of impression formation/updating (a social cognition task). Sample: 24 healthy adults aged 18–45. The paper reports whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (interaction and L2>F3 contrasts) with thresholding and cluster results (Table 1 and Supplementary Table 2), fulfilling whole-brain reporting requirements. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for task relevance, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-only, between-group-only contrasts, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical paper) apply.

This is an event-related fMRI study of affective speech comprehension (a social cognition / theory-of-mind task) in healthy adults (N=51, ages 18–53). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (EMO vs GRAM) with SPM analyses and FWE-corrected statistical maps/tables and figures. Behavioral and debriefing data support social-processing interpretation. Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and provides whole-brain task activation results.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (empathy/familiarity) in healthy adults (mean age 23.6; N=22). The task manipulates threat to self, friend, and stranger (a social-related task: perception/understanding of others, affiliation/attachment). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task contrasts and conjunction analyses (threat minus safe) using non-masked whole-brain analyses and cluster-wise thresholding; ROI analyses are secondary but whole-brain results are clearly reported in text, figures, tables, and supplementary materials. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and provision of whole-brain group-level statistical maps/results.

The study uses task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (effects of expert advice/social influence on decision-making), includes a healthy adult group (ages 18–45) with results reported separately, and reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses with cluster-corrected maps and peak coordinates (with figures/tables and supplementary material). Thus it satisfies the review’s requirements for (i) fMRI in a social task, (ii) a healthy adult sample, and (iii) whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise results (coordinates/figures).

This empirical fMRI study scanned healthy adult participants while they watched emotional movies probing social/emotional processing (social interaction, empathy-related constructs). The analysis reports multisubject voxelwise intersubject correlation (ISC) maps and region-level results (voxelwise synchronization in sensory, corticolimbic, and default-mode networks) described as group-level effects in the text, figures, and supporting information. Therefore it contains a social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain, group-level voxelwise results (acceptable if presented in figures/tables/SI). No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-affective processing (compassion/empathy) in healthy adult participants (N=94, females aged 18–35). The study used a socio-affective video task (SoVT) during fMRI and reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and contrasts (HE > LE, parametric modulations of empathy/affect) with FWE-corrected results and coordinate tables/figures clearly attributed to the healthy sample. Results include whole-brain activations (AI, aMCC, mOFC, putamen, VTA/SN, etc.) and are described in the main text and supplementary materials. Therefore it satisfies the review’s fMRI social-processing requirement, includes a healthy adult sample, and reports whole-brain healthy-group task effects.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (simulation/prediction of others' decisions) in healthy adult participants. The Methods report 36 healthy subjects (adult cohort) and group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses with corrected statistical maps, tables of coordinates, and figures (e.g., vmPFC, dmPFC/dlPFC activations) reporting task-evoked effects for the healthy group. The task is explicitly social (predicting another’s choices/outcomes). Thus it satisfies the review inclusion criteria for social fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, non-empirical) apply.

This is an original fMRI study that used task-based film stimuli to elicit social motivations (affiliation/romantic love and power) and measured BOLD responses. Participants were healthy adults (male students, mean age 23.6), satisfying the age and health requirements. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (affiliation > control; power > control) and regression analyses linking motive scores to activation, with cluster coordinates and FWE-corrected p-values provided in tables/figures. Whole-brain results are clearly described and reported as coordinates and figures. The study is neither ROI-only nor connectivity- or resting-state-only and provides unmasked healthy-group task effects. Therefore it meets the review inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=27, ages ~24–26) that uses task-based fMRI during observation of social interactions (cooperative vs. affective), directly addressing social cognition. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps (whole-brain FWE-corrected results and conjunction analyses), and provides coordinate tables/figures and ROI analyses. Healthy-control results are reported clearly and are not limited to a narrow subgroup. Thus it satisfies the review’s inclusion requirements for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study using naturalistic audiovisual stimuli specifically targeting multiple social features (faces, bodies, biological motion, social interaction, emotion, pain, speech, etc.). Participants were healthy adults (N=19, ages 21–34). The analysis used whole-brain, voxelwise GLM random-effects with group-level one-sample t-tests and reported thresholded whole-brain statistical maps (p<0.05 FDR) and coordinate tables/figures. The paper therefore meets the meta-analysis objectives and satisfies inclusion criteria for task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults with whole-brain group results.

This is an fMRI study of affiliative social processing in healthy adults (final N=27, ages 18–65 range implied). The task explicitly probes social-affiliative versus nonaffiliative scenarios, meeting the review’s social-related task requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., affiliative vs nonaffiliative; results surviving whole-brain and ROI FWE correction, with coordinates in Table 2 and figures), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Healthy/control-group effects are clearly presented (results are for the healthy participant sample, not limited to a subgroup). Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are satisfied.

The study reports task-based fMRI in adults (mothers mean age 24.1) using a social/attachment-related stimulus (own infant cry vs. control/other cry), meeting the social-related task requirement. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses are reported (FSL, thresholding, cluster tables/coordinates) and results for the healthy adult sample are clearly described. Participants are adults within the 18–65 range; although drawn from a higher-risk community and some had past perinatal depression, none met criteria for current major depressive episode at testing, and whole-brain healthy-group results are presented. Thus inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are satisfied.

This is an empirical fMRI study of perspective taking/empathy (social cognition), using task-based fMRI during social-related tasks (Self, Other, View) in healthy adult participants. Sample: 18 healthy right-handed adults aged 21–31 (within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Self vs Other, View-Pain vs View-No-Pain) with cluster- and peak-level FWE correction and provides tables of coordinates and time-course analyses. Thus it satisfies social-task fMRI (I3), healthy adult sample (I4), whole-brain group-level task activation maps reported (I5), and reports results as coordinates/tables (I6). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, outside age range) are met. Therefore the study should be included.

This fMRI study includes goal-directed social cognition tasks (social texts and social videos probing theory-of-mind/emotional states), tested in a sample of healthy adults (N=45, ages 19–23). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and provides peak coordinates and statistical maps/analyses (see Appendix A and whole-brain contrasts throughout the Results), with healthy/control group results clearly described. Therefore it satisfies the review inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and reports whole-brain results (coordinates/figures).

This is an empirical fMRI study that investigates perception of emotional facial expressions (social communication/perception) using task-based fMRI in humans and monkeys. The human sample comprises healthy adult participants (23 volunteers, ages 24–34). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain (random-effects) task-evoked statistical maps and associated coordinates, with cluster-corrected significance maps and figures described as coming from the healthy human group. Thus it meets the social-related task requirement, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting (including tables/figures), and the results are clearly described for the healthy/control group.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (action observation; why/how/what/how tasks) in healthy adults (N=19, ages 18–32). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise random-effects analyses and provides cluster coordinates and statistical maps (within an a priori mask, with whole-brain results and supplemental methods referenced), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results reported for the healthy/control group. Results are reported in tables/figures and supplemental material. Thus it meets the meta-analysis objectives and all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of visual perspective-taking (a social-cognitive/Theory-of-Mind task) in healthy adults. Participants: healthy right-handed adults (n=16, mean age 22.4) within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., Inconsistent Other > Consistent Other) with cluster-level FWE correction and tables of coordinates and statistical maps described in the text and tables. Analyses are not limited to ROIs, nor are they connectivity- or resting-state-only. Therefore the study meets all inclusion requirements for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=21, mean age 24) that uses action observation and execution paradigms addressing mirror-system responses—tasks directly relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’, a social cognition construct. The paper reports group-level voxelwise analyses including a whole-brain analysis (p<0.001 uncorrected) and ROI analyses, with second-level random-effects contrasts and reported peak coordinates, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results. The sample falls within the 18–65 age range and healthy-group results are reported separately. The study is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, nor non-empirical. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing: participants (n=22 healthy adults, mean age 25) underwent task-based fMRI while viewing dynamic social videos designed to evoke interactive vs. observational social cognition. The paper reports group-level random-effects (RFX) whole-brain ANOVA analyses and one-sample t-tests, with voxelwise results presented (ROI small-volume corrections were applied for hypothesis testing, and an exploratory whole-brain analysis revealed early visual (V1) activation). Peak coordinates (MNI) and group-level contrasts are reported for the healthy participant group. Thus the study uses task fMRI of social constructs (I3), includes healthy adult participants (I4), provides group-level voxelwise task-evoked results (I5), and reports coordinates/figures consistent with acceptable whole-brain reporting (I6). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) apply.

This is an fMRI study that directly manipulates social information (trustworthiness of faces) during an n-back working memory task. Participants were healthy adults (mean age 22, right-handed, neurologically normal) within the 18–65 range. The paper reports voxel-wise, whole-brain group-level analyses (2×2 repeated-measures ANOVA) with cluster correction and provides peak coordinates and tables/figures of activation maps for the healthy sample. All required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state-only, out-of-range sample) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (mean age ~21) that used a social-related task (perception/empathy for others’ pain). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation contrasts (painful vs non-painful) with tables of coordinates and FDR-corrected whole-brain results for the pre- and post-priming sessions, and describes whole-brain analyses in the text and figures. All specified inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This paper reports original fMRI data using social-related tasks (fame recognition and social closeness judgments), which map onto social perception/understanding of others. The sample consists of healthy adult participants (final N=15 females, mean age 22.33), within the 18–65 range. The authors present group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (random-effects GLM; voxelwise FDR and cluster-corrected thresholds) and report peak coordinates from whole-brain analyses. Results and coordinates are clearly described in text/tables and figures. The study is empirical and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

The study used task-based fMRI to examine perception of face gender, which is a social-related construct (Perception and Understanding of Others). Participants were healthy adults (ages 19–42; N=16 with one excluded). The paper reports both ROI and whole-brain, voxel-wise random-effects group analyses (gender-different > gender-same contrast) with cluster-corrected group activation maps and reported coordinates, satisfying the requirement for a group-level whole-brain task-evoked map. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, includes healthy adult group, empirical task fMRI results are reported). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (mean age 23.5; final N=17) using a social decision-making task that manipulates human vs computer opponents and interpersonal conflict for resources. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Conflict > No Conflict; Human Conflict > Computer Conflict), with tables of coordinates and statistical maps described in the text and figures. Results for the healthy/control group are reported clearly. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age out of range, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all specified inclusion criteria and is suitable for the meta-analysis of task-evoked social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=24, age 18–27) that used task-based whole-brain voxelwise analyses to examine neural responses during Why-How and Categories-Exemplars tasks. These tasks probe action understanding and construal of others’ behavior (e.g., “why do people…?”), engaging mentalizing and action-observation systems and thus qualify as social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation maps with coordinates and corrected thresholds (Table 2, whole-brain contrasts and conjunctions). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adult group-level task effects).

This is an empirical fMRI study of attractiveness (beauty) comparisons—a social perception/understanding of others—conducted in healthy adult participants (25 right-handed British women, mean age 23.46). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (distance effects, conjunctions, main effects) with tables of MNI coordinates and thresholding details; ROI analyses are also reported but whole-brain voxelwise results for the healthy group are clearly presented. Thus the study directly addresses the review objective and satisfies whole-brain reporting requirements.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults using a social interaction (cyberball) and face-perception task with pre/post learning fMRI acquisitions. Sample: 15 healthy adults (mean age 24.1), meeting age and health criteria. The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses: an exploratory searchlight whole-brain analysis yielded significant, corrected decreases in pattern similarity in superior temporal sulcus (coordinates and t-values reported), fulfilling the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results. Results are reported at the group level for the healthy sample. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

This paper reports task-based fMRI of social cognition (mentalizing about groups and individuals) in healthy adult participants (Experiments: N=25, ages 19–27; N=14, ages 18–23), satisfying the population criterion. It includes whole-brain, group-level voxelwise contrasts (e.g., group mental > group physical; member mental > member physical; individual mental > individual physical) with tables of coordinates and statistical maps reported, and uses multivariate searchlight and whole-brain random-effects analyses. Results for the healthy/control sample are reported directly. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy or out-of-range sample, or non-empirical paper) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study that directly examines social processing (learning from romantic interest/rejection) using a speed-dating task and event-related fMRI. The scanned sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=38, ages 19–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked results (SPM8 analyses) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction for multiple comparisons, and displays whole-brain contrasts (e.g., Yes > No, Match > Unrequited, mismatched > matched). Results for healthy participants are presented clearly and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=23, mean age ~24) that investigates social-communication processes (communicative vs private intentions) using task-based fMRI. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., CInt > PInt, interaction effects) with tables of peak coordinates and thresholding information, and includes figures of whole-brain results. Behavioral methods, imaging parameters, preprocessing, and second-level whole-brain analyses are described. Thus the study meets all required inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social-affective regulation using a hand-holding threat paradigm (social-related task: affiliation/attachment). Sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=22, mean age 23.6), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses: multisubject ROIs were identified via cluster-wise tests using FSL with standard Z-thresholds and cluster p-thresholds; Table 1 lists ROIs, coordinates, maxima and cluster sizes derived from these group-level contrasts (threat minus safe). Results are reported as group-level task-evoked activation maps/contrasts and described in the text and tables. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=18, mean age 26) that uses task-based fMRI to probe social-related processing (explicit laughter type categorization and implicit bout counting) and reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (CSL>TIC, TIC>CSL, CAT>COU) with thresholds and corrections. Whole-brain results are described in the text, figures, and cluster-level inferences. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult task fMRI and reports whole-brain task-evoked maps.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (imitation of communicative gestures) in healthy adults (20 right-handed males, mean age 24.6). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., IMI > CT, S > NS, interactions) with peak coordinates and cluster statistics in tables and figures, clearly from the healthy sample. Whole-brain results are reported in tables of coordinates and discussed in the text. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for fMRI social-related tasks, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults that uses a social-related task (viewing images of human suffering while applying compassion or reappraisal) directly addressing perception/understanding of others and prosocial behavior. The sample is healthy adults (ages 18–45) and results for the healthy participants are reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (e.g., whole-brain Group × Redistribution Rank interaction with Monte Carlo–corrected results identifying right IPC and conjunction/DLPFC results; ROI-corrected PPI results are supplemental), and whole-brain results are described in text, figures, and supplementary material. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study examining social-related processing (rewards for self, friend, antagonist) in healthy adults (N=31, ages 18–26). Group-level whole-brain task analyses are reported (ANOVAs, voxelwise results with tables of MNI coordinates and corrected clusters), satisfying whole-brain evidence reporting.
