Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication/influence (mentalizing, reward during encoding of ideas) in healthy adult participants (interns N=19, producers N=79; mean ages ≈20.5). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (random-effects whole-brain contrasts; thresholding and Monte Carlo correction) and provides coordinates and tables/figures for activation (Table 1, reported MNI coordinates). Thus it meets the review’s requirements for fMRI social-related tasks, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain voxelwise results.

This is an empirical fMRI study investigating social cognition (recognition of vitality forms) in healthy adult participants (N=19; ages 21–29). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., how vs what; what vs implicit/static baseline) with tables of MNI coordinates and figures, clearly describing results for the healthy sample. Thus it meets the review’s fMRI social-task requirement, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting criteria.

The study is an empirical task-based fMRI investigation of social cognition (theory of mind, emotion, pain) in healthy adults. Sample: 46 healthy female participants aged 18–31 (within 18–65). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses (univariate contrasts with cluster-corrected results and tables of coordinates) and whole-brain MVPA results. Healthy/control-group results are reported explicitly. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for fMRI during social-related tasks, a healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task activation reporting. No exclusion criteria appear to be violated.

The study reports task-based fMRI during a social-evaluation paradigm (being observed by a peer), fulfilling the social-related task requirement. The sample is healthy and includes adults (ages up to 22.9 years), meeting the criterion of having healthy adult participants. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked results (e.g., MPFC activation and MPFC–striatum connectivity) with corrected statistical maps and coordinates, clearly derived from the healthy participant group. Whole-brain results are reported in the main text and figures (and supplemental material). Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social perception using a social-related task (rating naturalness of dyadic nonverbal interactions) in healthy adult participants (21 males, ages 23–33). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task activation contrasts and provides tables of coordinates and cluster-level results for the healthy/control group (e.g., contingent > mirrored; rigid > smooth), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This is an fMRI study of social impression formation (perception/understanding of others) using task-based BOLD imaging (I3). The sample comprises healthy adults (N=19, mean age 19.1) within the 18–65 range (I4). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses and provides voxelwise results with Talairach coordinates and cluster sizes (Tables 1 and 2) and cluster-corrected statistical thresholds, satisfying the whole-brain reporting requirement (I5, I6). No exclusion criteria apply (e.g., not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a review, and reports healthy-group task effects).

The study reports task-based functional MRI of social perception (passive viewing of point-light biological motion), includes a healthy adult sample (n=48; ages 20–35), and provides group-level, whole-brain voxelwise results (main effect biological>scrambled motion and Sex×Condition ANOVA) for the adult healthy group reported in tables and figures. Whole-brain maps and coordinate tables are presented; PPI analyses are supplementary but do not replace whole-brain task activation reporting. Thus all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults (ages 19–28). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., E–O, S–X) with coordinates, statistical maps, and cluster-level inference; tasks explicitly probe social perception (eye-gaze, self-propelling motion) and an implicit mental inference role-playing task. Healthy adult sample and group-level results are clearly reported. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (third-party punishment; mentalizing about others’ intentions) in healthy adult participants (n=26, mean age 26). The study reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (random-effects GLM; FDR threshold q<0.05) and provides peak coordinates and statistical maps (reported R TPJ and R anterior insula activations). Results for the healthy control group are clearly described. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-age-range) apply. Therefore it satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion requirements for whole-brain fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (male drivers, ages ~19–30) that uses a social-related task (viewing traffic-awareness videos eliciting social cognition: empathy/mentalizing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (CV vs NV) with whole-brain analyses and figures/tables showing voxelwise results for the healthy groups (safe and dangerous drivers). Results are presented as whole-brain maps and tables of coordinates. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social tasks in healthy adults and provides whole-brain group-level activation maps.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (passive viewing of faces vs objects; perception/understanding of others). The sample includes a healthy adult group (ages 18–37) reported separately in descriptive and ROI analyses. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (faces>objects contrast) and provides whole-brain results with tables of coordinates (Table 3) and figures, clearly derived from the healthy sample. Therefore it satisfies the meta-analysis requirements for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study used task-based functional MRI during a social-cognitive attribute framing task (self and reflected perspectives), directly addressing social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Self). The sample comprised healthy adults aged 19–41 with group-level analyses reported. The paper reports multiple group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., positive minus negative, negative minus positive, frame-inconsistent minus frame-consistent) with thresholding and cluster-size correction described, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. Results are presented as whole-brain contrasts in the main text and figures/tables. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an fMRI study of social processing: participants made approachability judgments of faces (social perception of others). The paper reports group-level task contrasts (interaction between task and face valence) with whole-brain activations described in the text (left amygdala, medial/middle/inferior frontal gyri) and correlations with trait anxiety, indicating healthy adult participants were analyzed as a group. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore inclusion criteria I3 (social-related fMRI task), I4 (healthy adult sample reported), I5 (whole-brain group-level task-evoked maps), and I6 (whole-brain results reported in text/figures) are met. Confidence is slightly reduced because exact participant age range is not explicit in the provided excerpt, but the study context (adult psychiatry/neuroscience sample) and typical reporting support inclusion.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (empathy/emotional egocentricity) in healthy adult participants. The paper reports multiple group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (random-effects analyses) including coordinates and statistical maps (fMRI Experiment 1 whole-brain exploratory analysis; fMRI Experiment 2 used independent VOI/SVC but also conducted whole-brain analyses and reports peak coordinates), and clearly describes results for the healthy/control group. Participants are healthy adults (female undergraduate samples, total N=191 across experiments) in the target age range. Therefore it meets the review's inclusion criteria for task modality, sample, and whole-brain reporting.

This is an event-related fMRI study using a Dynamic Social Gesture task contrasting social vs nonsocial interactions, meeting the review’s focus on social-related processing (I3). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (mean age 21.4; range includes late adolescents but the group is healthy adults within 18–65), meeting the sample requirement (I4). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation results (TFCE with permutation testing) with coordinates, figures, and tables, satisfying whole-brain evidence criteria (I5,I6). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be included.

This study reports an fMRI experiment manipulating social context (collaboration, competition) during an effort task — a social-related task probing perception/understanding of others and social motivation. Participants were healthy adults (N=32; ages 18–39), meeting the age/sample criterion. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (GLM SPMs, clusterwise FWE correction reported), with activation maps, coordinates, and tables described in the text and figures. Thus all inclusion criteria are satisfied (I3, I4, I5, I6). No exclusion criteria apply (no ROI-only, no connectivity-only, no out-of-range ages, and this is empirical fMRI data).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=20, ages 23–39) that used task-based fMRI while participants judged ambiguous social interactions (social coordination vs. relationship familiarity). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., rough>no priming, rough>smooth) with FDR-corrected results, tables of peak coordinates, and statistical maps described in the text and figures. Thus it meets the review's requirements for social-related processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked results. No exclusion criteria are triggered.

This paper reports a structural MRI (voxel-based morphometry) study of grey matter volumes and proneness to moral sentiments in healthy adults. Although it references and uses previously acquired fMRI-derived peak responses in a subgroup (N=29), the article itself does not present group-level, whole-brain task-evoked fMRI statistical maps from a social task for the healthy group. Therefore it does not meet the core inclusion criteria requiring (I3) use of functional MRI during a social-related task in the reported study and (I5) reporting of a whole-brain task-evoked healthy-group activation map. The sample is healthy adults (meets I4), but absence of original whole-brain fMRI task results disqualifies it for this fMRI-focused meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of live verbal communication (social communication) using a task where participants speak/listen about autobiographical events. Sample comprises 22 healthy adult participants (11 pairs of women; mean age 27.2) within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise second-level t-tests for task effects (talking, listening, imagining) and inter-subject coupling analyses, with tables/figures and cluster-thresholding described; results for the healthy group are clearly reported. Therefore it satisfies the review inclusion criteria for task, sample, and whole-brain reporting.

This is an fMRI study of explicit social judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) on vocal stimuli in healthy adults (N=44; ages 21–60). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects ANOVA), cluster-level FWE-corrected results, and tables of MNI coordinates for activation peaks. Results are reported for the healthy sample rather than only between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI tasks, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked maps.

This is an empirical, task-based fMRI study of social communication/empathy using naturalistic videos (addresses social communication/empathy constructs). The sample comprises 27 healthy adults (mean age 34), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM results and multiple voxelwise contrasts (e.g., E > N, channel-specific contrasts and conjunctions) presented as figures and coordinate-based findings. Although the paper also presents effective connectivity (DCM), it clearly provides healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps, satisfying the review requirements. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study examining empathy, Theory of Mind, and self–other differentiation using task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (male, age 21–40). The tasks are social-cognitive (empathy, ToM, self-reference) using IAPS images, meeting the review’s social-related task requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects, whole-brain ANOVA and contrasts) with coordinates and cluster results presented in tables and figures, clearly from the healthy/control group. Thus it meets all required inclusion criteria and does not violate listed exclusion criteria.

This study used event-related functional MRI during a social task (one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma), involved healthy adult participants (mean age 24.6) and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise GLM results with cluster-corrected statistical maps and tables/figures of coordinates. These elements meet the review’s requirements for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This paper reports a task-based fMRI study involving social-related processing (familiar vs unfamiliar faces; perception/understanding of others/attachment). It includes a separately reported healthy control group (13 older healthy volunteers) and presents group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts for the control group (partner>unfamiliar) with coordinates and cluster-level FWE-corrected results. Whole-brain results are reported in tables/figures and described in the text. The study therefore meets I3, I4, I5 and I6. Confidence is slightly reduced because the control group are older adults (mean age 64.5 ±5.7), close to the 65-year upper bound of the target age range, but healthy-group whole-brain data are clearly reported.

This study reports task-based fMRI during a social decision-making task (multiround Ultimatum Game), includes a healthy adult group (n=15, ages 19–28), and presents group-level whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (one-sample t-tests per group and full-factorial ANOVAs) with statistical maps and tables of coordinates (contrast unfair > fair). Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately and displayed in figures/tables (thresholded maps and peak coordinates), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Therefore all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults are met.

This is an fMRI study of live reciprocal imitation, an online social-interaction task (social communication/perception of others). The sample comprised healthy adult participants (23 right-handed females, ages 18–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain GLM task contrasts (imitating, being imitated, observation vs rest) with familywise error correction (p<0.05) and provides coordinates/tables and figures of whole-brain activations. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, they are supplemental to and do not replace the reported whole-brain task activation maps. Thus the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 and does not violate exclusion criteria (e.g., it is not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and includes healthy adults).

Although this task-based fMRI study involves healthy adult participants and examines social aspects of direct touch, the reported neuroimaging results are based on group independent component analysis (ICA) spatial maps and component time courses. The paper does not present a conventional group-level, voxelwise task-evoked activation map or within-group GLM contrasts (e.g., SPM/T-map) clearly identified as coming from the healthy group. Per the review’s exclusion criteria, studies that report only connectivity/ICA analyses without also reporting a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map should be excluded. Therefore this study does not meet the required whole-brain task-activation reporting standard.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a face-perception task (faces vs houses) which is a social-related process (perception/understanding of others). The sample includes healthy adults (undergraduates, mean age 18.9), with a subset (N=22) completing fMRI. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain second-level GLM results and presents significant clusters (Table 2) and whole-brain activation maps (FWE-corrected), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Healthy-group task effects are reported separately (not only between-group contrasts or ROIs). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study used task-based fMRI including social-distance trials (names and photos of friends vs acquaintances), fulfilling the requirement for social-related processing. The sample comprised healthy adult participants (n=15, ages 20–28). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (searchlight MVPA and representational similarity analyses) with statistical maps and group conjunction tests identifying clusters (e.g., right IPL) and presents whole-brain results (figures/tables). Reporting format satisfies acceptability (figures/tables of coordinates and description). No exclusion criteria apply.

Although this paper uses fMRI during a social-related task in healthy participants, the fMRI results are reported as ROI-based analyses (ROIs derived from VBM peaks and AAL masks) with beta weights extracted and tested, and no group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps for the healthy group are presented. The review requires at least one whole-brain, group-level task-evoked map (I5). Because the study reports only ROI analyses for the fMRI task and no unmasked whole-brain healthy-group activation maps, it violates the eligibility requirement and must be excluded.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (direct self, direct other, reflected self; social/academic/physical domains), satisfying the social-related task requirement. It includes a healthy adult group (N=19, ages 22–31) analyzed and reported separately from the adolescent group. Whole-brain, voxelwise group-level analyses were conducted (2×4×3 whole-brain ANOVA) with multiple-comparison correction (AlphaSim) and significant clusters reported with coordinates (e.g., bilateral ventral striatum), and results are described in text, figures, and supplementary materials. Thus, whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps/contrasts are available. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult-only sample, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (bystander effect) in healthy adults. The study used task-based functional MRI during observation of emergencies (social context) while participants performed an unrelated color-naming task, meeting the social-related task requirement. Participants were healthy adults aged 18–27. Analyses include whole-brain, group-level random-effects GLMs and report voxelwise statistical maps and tables of coordinates (parametric and contrasts), fulfilling whole-brain reporting standards. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, non-empirical) apply.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (causal attribution/mentalizing) in healthy adults (N=20, ages 18–41). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (each attribution locus > truth baseline), conjunctions, and a whole-brain analysis with coordinates and FWE-corrected results (see Table 1 and figures). Results are reported for the healthy/control sample (not limited to a subgroup). Whole-brain results are presented as coordinate tables and described in the text. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This paper reports an fMRI study of social-related processing (attributing awareness to others) in healthy adult participants (n=50; ages 18–49). It includes whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task contrasts (H trials − E trials) thresholded and corrected (P < 0.05, cluster-size correction) with coordinates reported in Table 1 and surface maps shown (Fig. 3), satisfying reporting requirements. The sample and analyses pertain to healthy adults and the whole-brain task activation maps are clearly described. Therefore all relevant inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using social tasks (Cyberball exclusion and a modified Dictator Game) addressing social processing (punishment and forgiveness of excluders). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=26, mean age 20.7), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Excluders > Includers; Excluders equality > Includers equality) with tables of MNI coordinates and notes FDR-corrected clusters. Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of anticipatory interpersonal touch (a social/haptic task) in healthy adult participants (n=16, ages 20–34). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxel-wise task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (target, modality, interaction effects) with cluster-level correction and tables/coordinates. Results are described for the healthy participant group (not limited to a subgroup), and whole-brain findings are provided in text, figures, and Table 1. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for an fMRI social-processing task in healthy adults with whole-brain evidence. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) apply.

This is a task-based fMRI study of self-referential/social cognition (conceptual vs agentic self/other recollection), conducted in healthy adult participants (age range 19–29). The paper reports group-level voxelwise task-evoked activation contrasts with coordinate tables and whole-brain results (including FWE-corrected whole-brain clusters and conjunction analyses), clearly from the healthy participant sample. Thus it satisfies the meta-analysis requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=21, Mage=23.1) that examines social-related processing (self-referential processing and intergroup competition). The methods report whole-brain, group-level random-effects analyses and present voxelwise results and coordinates in Tables 1 and 2 (cluster-wise corrected thresholds) and accompanying figures, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. Participants are within the 18–65 range and are healthy; results for the healthy group are reported. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults and reports group-level whole-brain results.

This study used task-based fMRI to examine facial color processing—a form of social perception relevant to ‘perception and understanding of others’ (social communication/emotion cues). The sample consists of 25 healthy adults (mean age 25.24), meeting the age and healthy-sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (natural-colored faces vs scrambled images) with MNI coordinates, clusters, figures, and tables, satisfying the whole-brain reporting requirement. Results and coordinates are clearly described in text/tables/figures. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state/connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical paper) apply. Therefore all inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are met.

This is an fMRI study that directly investigates social feedback processing (a social-related task) in healthy adult participants (German and Chinese adults). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation results (whole-brain FWE-corrected clusters and tables of activations) for the healthy groups, including contrasts and parametric modulation analyses. Results are clearly attributed to the healthy/control groups. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for task relevance, sample, and whole-brain reporting.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social influence/emotion alignment using an interactive task where participants viewed and rated affective pictures while seeing an interaction partner’s ratings. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (mean age ~24, right-handed students). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (parametric modulators; clusterwise FWE-corrected results) with tables and figures describing activations (insula, amygdala, ventral striatum). Whole-brain results are clearly reported in text, tables and figures. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20, mean age 24.6) that uses a social-related task: viewing first-person-perspective video clips of neutral, social-positive, and reactive-aggressive interactions to probe social/emotional processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and conjunctions with tables of coordinates and FDR-corrected statistics (Tables 2–3) and describes within-group contrasts for the healthy sample. Thus it provides whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for healthy adults relevant to social constructs. All inclusion criteria for the review are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others’ interactions using point-light biological motion) in healthy adults. The sample includes healthy adult males aged 22–32. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (atypical vs. typical displays) with cluster-level correction and provides tables of activation coordinates. Thus it satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion criteria for task fMRI in healthy adults and reports whole-brain results.

This fMRI study (NeuroImage, 2014) investigates social-related processing (imagined triadic social interactions) using task-based fMRI in a sample of healthy adults (N=19, age 18–35). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., triad > iron; conjunction analyses) with family-wise error correction and tables/figures of whole-brain results, and provides coordinates and supplementary materials. Thus it meets all required inclusion criteria for healthy adult task-based whole-brain fMRI reporting.

Although this is an fMRI study of a social task (Ultimatum Game) in healthy adult participants and reports group-level contrasts, the second-level analyses were performed within a restricted mask comprising 16 bilateral ROIs (wfu_pickatlas). The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain voxelwise group-level task activation map; results are effectively ROI-restricted. This meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, and acceptable reporting format I6, but violates the requirement for whole-brain group-level results (exclusion criterion E2: ROI-only analyses). Therefore the study should be excluded from the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults using a social-interactive task (an fMRI-adapted Taylor Aggression Paradigm presenting opponents’ facial expressions). Participants were healthy adults (male, mean age 23.3; N=32 analyzed). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (angry > neutral) with cluster-wise FWE correction and tables/figures of whole-brain results (Tables 1–2, whole-brain contrasts described in text), satisfying whole-brain evidence. ROI analyses are supplemental but are not the only reported results. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adults (N=16, ages 18–25) during a social competitive task (matching-pennies) involving human and non-human agents. Whole-brain, voxelwise GLM analyses with parametric modulators are reported, including voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and peak coordinates/tables and figures are provided. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for an fMRI social task in healthy adults with group-level whole-brain task activation results.

This is an fMRI study of impression formation (social evaluation of others), conducted in healthy adult participants (N=20, ages 19–31). The task is clearly social (person evaluation/impression formation). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (exploratory whole-brain ANOVA with activations reported in Table 1 and figures) in the healthy sample. Whole-brain results are presented as coordinate tables and figures. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults with whole-brain reporting.

The study is an fMRI investigation of implicit theory-of-mind (social cognition) in healthy adults (initial N=20; MRI analyses N=16; mean age 22.7). It uses a task-based social paradigm (Sally–Anne movies) and reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM results (belief > photo/map from the explicit ToM localizer) with voxelwise statistical maps, peak coordinates, cluster thresholds, and figures. The paper also presents whole-brain SPM contrasts for implicit false-belief > true-belief and ROI analyses derived from the localizer. Thus it provides task-evoked, healthy-group whole-brain activation maps and satisfies the review’s MRI and reporting requirements.

The study reports an fMRI investigation of interpersonal synchrony (a social-related task) in a sample of healthy adult participants (total N=100). The abstract and neuroimaging description indicate group-level task-evoked neural effects with reported involvement of multiple brain areas implicated in social and embodied cognition, consistent with whole-brain activation reporting. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 18–65, and is an empirical fMRI study). Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI task study probing socio-emotional processing (empathy induction) using campaign vs. control videos — a clear social-related task. Participants were healthy adults (20 right-handed male volunteers, ages 20–28). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (CV>NV contrast) with FWE-corrected results and peak coordinates used as ROIs; effects are described in text/tables/figures. Thus it meets the review’s task, sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of cross-modal person recognition (voice-face priming), a social perception task (perception/understanding of others). Participants were healthy adults (n=16, ages 20–31). Group-level fMRI analyses were performed using SPM and random-effects models; the paper reports group-level activation coordinates (e.g., FFA, OFA, aTL) from the face localizer and task contrasts, with results presented as voxelwise contrasts and corrected statistics (ROI and coordinate reporting). Whole-brain preprocessing and analyses were described; group-level activation coordinates are provided in the text/tables/figures. Although several results are ROI-corrected and PPIs are reported, the paper includes task-evoked, group-level voxelwise results for the healthy sample. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This fMRI study used a social-related task (perception of biological motion) and examined neural responses related to social processing. Participants were healthy adults (ages 18–39). The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses of biological-motion selectivity correlated with social-network measures (including cluster-level corrected results in right pSTS), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results. Reporting of whole-brain results is clearly described in the text and supplemental material. Therefore all inclusion criteria for this review are met.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=50, ages 18–29) that examines labeling of briefly presented emotional facial expressions—a social cognitive task involving perception and understanding of others’ emotions. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation contrasts (HA>NE, AN>NE, FE>NE) with cluster-level FWE-corrected results and coordinate tables/figures. Results are presented for the healthy sample separately. Therefore it meets the meta-analysis requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps.

This fMRI study directly investigates social-related processing (social sharing of emotions/affiliation) using a task manipulating shared vs unshared viewing (meets I3). Sample comprises healthy adult participants aged 20–33 with fMRI data reported for n=26 (meets I4). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses and whole-brain corrected activations (e.g., DLPFC and precuneus) in addition to ROI results, and describes voxelwise contrasts for the healthy sample (meets I5 and I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication in healthy adults (female participants aged 19–28) that uses a social-related task (receivers believing text messages came from a friend vs a computer). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses (univariate contrasts, searchlight MVPA, and MVCA) with cluster results and coordinates (Table 2, figures) clearly identified for the healthy participant group. Reporting includes whole-brain statistical maps and coordinate tables. Thus all required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (dynamic social tie formation during a repeated public good game), meeting the review objective. The sample includes healthy adult participants (25 scanned; mean age ~22.6) reported separately, satisfying the age/sample requirement. The authors report whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task-evoked analyses (GLM with cluster-wise FWE correction) and provide peak coordinates and statistical maps/results in the text and supplementary tables/figures. Parametric modulation and connectivity analyses are reported but are accompanied by unmasked whole-brain task activation maps. Thus inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 are satisfied, and no exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) apply.

This empirical study used simultaneous fMRI in pairs performing a communicative task (social communication) with healthy adult participants (N=54, ages 18–27). The analysis includes group-level whole-brain voxelwise contrasts and searches (random-effects analysis, cluster-level correction) and reports anatomical results (e.g., rSTG) and whole-brain inference procedures. The task clearly probes social-related processing (mutual understanding, communication). Thus it satisfies use of fMRI during a social task, healthy adult sample, and reporting of whole-brain group-level task-evoked results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical, or outside age range) apply.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (joint attention) in healthy adults. The sample consists of neurologically healthy adults (final N=13, mean age ~24.85), meeting the adult age range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., RJA - RJAc, IJA - IJAc), with FDR-corrected statistical maps and tables of coordinates and figures presenting whole-brain results. Control conditions and contrasts are clearly described and results are reported for the healthy/control group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

The conference abstract indicates dyadic fMRI during eye contact (social task), so I3 is likely met. However the full text provided does not report participant characteristics or ages (I4 cannot be confirmed) and does not present or describe any group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation maps (I5 not met). The abstract focuses on network synchronizations and a data-driven neural basis without clear whole-brain statistical maps for a healthy adult group. Because a qualifying whole-brain healthy-group task activation map is not reported, the study fails inclusion requirements. Exclusion is based primarily on lack of reported whole-brain task activation results (E3).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=37, mean age 25) investigating social communication (feeling addressed) using video stimuli with manipulations of body orientation and co-speech gestures. The study reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (main effects and interactions) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster-level inference, and describes whole-brain preprocessing and SPM analyses. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for fMRI during a social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social perception in healthy adults (N=12; ages 21–31) using a social-related task (viewing and categorizing person dyads), fulfilling the review objective. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain GLM analyses with voxelwise thresholding and cluster correction and provides peak coordinates and tables/figures (e.g., Table 3, whole-brain contrasts), meeting whole-brain evidence reporting requirements. Healthy adult participant results are reported independently. Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of emotional crowds and interactions), conducted in healthy adult participants (N=16, ages 19–27). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects ANOVAs) with cluster-corrected results and tables of peak coordinates and cluster sizes, clearly from the healthy sample. Thus it satisfies the review requirements for task relevance, sample, and whole-brain reporting.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (deception, theory-of-mind in strategic interaction) using a sender–receiver interactive task (meets social-related task). Sample comprises healthy adults (n=34, age range 21–32) with results reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., simple deception vs. truth, sophisticated deception vs. truth, parametric analyses) with Bayesian second-level probability maps and tables of coordinates/activations and figures, satisfying whole-brain reporting. There is no evidence of ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical study issues. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults that reports whole-brain, group-level task-evoked activation maps. The task required participants to predict others' behavior (social cognition/ToM and deontic reasoning). Sample: 18 healthy adults aged 18–44, within the 18–65 range. The paper reports voxelwise whole-brain results (tables and figures of coordinates, cluster- and voxel-level corrected results) for portrait and feedback events and contrasts (e.g., desires > rules), clearly from the healthy/control group. Thus it meets criteria for fMRI social task (I3), healthy adult sample (I4), whole-brain group-level results (I5), and acceptable reporting of whole-brain results in tables/figures (I6). No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study using dyadic fMRI during a social task (eye contact), with healthy adult participants (19 pairs; ages 18–33). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain GLM analyses and paired t-tests, provides activation maps, cluster results, MNI coordinates, and atlas-based labeling (i.e., whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy group). Thus it meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only without task maps, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) apply.

This is an fMRI study of social attribution (why/how task) examining neural correlates of understanding others’ mental states. Sample comprises healthy adults (N=19, ages 21–46). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task activation analyses (one-sample t tests, conjunctions, cluster-forming threshold p<.001 and cluster-level FWE .05) with whole-brain results presented in tables and figures. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study using a social-affective mimicry task probing affiliation-related processes (responses to happy vs angry faces and in-/out-group membership). Sample consists of healthy adult participants (final fMRI sample N=41, ages ~22). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (Incongruent>Congruent and masked contrasts) with tables of stereotactic coordinates and cluster-level corrected results, clearly from the healthy/control group. Whole-brain results are presented in main text/tables and supplementary materials. Therefore it satisfies the meta-analysis requirements for inclusion.

This is an empirical fMRI study that directly investigates social reward processing using a social incentive delay task. The sample consists of healthy adult participants within the 18–65 range (ages ~20–36) and results are reported for the healthy cohort. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and whole-brain FWE-corrected results (tables and figures) for anticipation and outcome contrasts (e.g., Tables 2–4, whole-brain results described in text). Thus it satisfies the requirements for fMRI task-based social processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognitive processing (social working memory) in healthy adult participants (N=25, mean age 21.6). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (conjunctions and contrasts), with tables of cluster coordinates and figures, and clearly identifies results from the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets I3 (fMRI during a social-related task), I4 (healthy adult sample 18–65), I5 (group-level whole-brain voxelwise maps reported), and I6 (results reported via tables/figures). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social gaze processing (social attention/gaze following) in healthy adult participants (N=21, mean age 24.6). The task is social-related (observing eye contact and gaze cues) and uses functional MRI (I3). The sample consists of healthy adults within the 18–65 range (I4). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (random-effects one-sample t-tests) with thresholding and tables/figures of activations (I5, I6). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and is eligible for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (20 participants, ages 19–31) that includes multiple social-task contrasts (ToM, faces, biological motion, voices, language). However, although first-level whole-brain GLMs were computed, the group-level voxelwise analyses reported in the paper were restricted to a bilateral STS mask (i.e., ROI-constrained second-level analyses). The paper does not present an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. Therefore it fails inclusion criterion I5 (group-level whole-brain task-evoked map) and falls under exclusion criterion E2 (studies reporting only ROI-masked results with no whole-brain results).

This is an fMRI study of action conceptualization that explicitly engages social-cognitive processes (mentalizing/theory-of-mind networks) and contrasts why/how conceptualizations. Participants were healthy adults (N=17, ages 21–46). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (one-sample t-tests, cluster-forming threshold p<0.001 and cluster-level FWE correction) and presents whole-brain results and tables. Results are not limited to ROI-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study that investigates processing of emotional (angry, happy faces) and neutral (shapes) stimuli using task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample (N=30, mean age ~24). The paradigm involves social-emotional face processing (implicit gender identification) and neutral control stimuli, satisfying the social-related task requirement. Group-level, whole-brain second-level (random-effects) analyses and contrasts (e.g., main effects of stimulus type and interactions) are reported and thresholded (FWE-corrected), with results presented in figures/tables and ROI analyses; thus whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise maps for the healthy group are available. Participants are healthy adults within the 18–65 range. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) apply. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for the review.

This study reports task-based fMRI in an interactive mentalizing (Prisoner’s Dilemma) paradigm, examining adult attachment effects. The sample is 164 healthy adult participants, satisfying the age and healthy-group requirement. The paper describes robust activation of the mentalizing network (bilateral precuneus, cingulate cortices, IFG, TPJ, medial frontal gyri, amygdala, etc.) and reports correlations of attachment dimensions with task-associated neural activity, indicating group-level whole-brain task-evoked results rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets the review’s focus on social-related processing in healthy adults and provides whole-brain, voxelwise task activation evidence.

This is an fMRI study investigating neural correlates of the urge to imitate during an observation/imitation task, which pertains to social-related processing (perception/understanding of others; social communication). The sample comprises 37 healthy adult participants (age range 18–25), satisfying the healthy adult sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (parametric modulation contrasts for Urge, Familiarity, Difficulty, Rhythm) with reported statistical thresholds and cluster-level correction; coordinates and activation maps are described. PPI connectivity is also reported but does not replace the whole-brain task activations. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants within 18–65, empirical fMRI data).

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (undergraduates aged 18–21) using a social-related task (viewing social vs non-social scenes). The paper reports group-level whole-brain, random-effects task contrast (social > non-social) with voxelwise results, coordinates, and tables (FDR corrected, p<0.05, k>25). Thus it meets the fMRI social-processing objective and provides whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps.

This is an fMRI study using a task probing social reputation (social-related processing) in healthy adult participants (N=28, ages 20–24). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., positive vs. neutral, negative vs. neutral) with cluster-level FWE correction and peak coordinates in MNI space. Results are clearly presented for the healthy participant group. Thus it satisfies task-based fMRI social construct (I3), healthy adult sample (I4), and whole-brain group-level task-evoked results reported (I5,I6).

This empirical fMRI study (NeuroImage, 2015) used the EmpaToM task to probe social-cognitive processes (empathy and Theory of Mind), thus addressing social-related processing. The samples are healthy adult participants (Experiments 1 and 2; Experiment 2 N=178, mean age 40.9, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., emotionally negative > neutral; ToM > nonToM) with tables of peak coordinates and figures, and applies whole-brain correction thresholds. Therefore it meets all inclusion requirements and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 18–36) using a social gaze-following task probing political in-group/out-group effects. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (incongruent > congruent) with voxelwise results and cluster-level corrections (Table 3, figures), and provides ROI and whole-brain analyses for the healthy sample. Sample and analyses meet the review’s requirements for healthy adult participants and whole-brain task activation reporting. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a social Theory-of-Mind task (animated interacting shapes), reporting task-evoked, group-level whole-brain contrasts (ToM > Random, ToM > Baseline) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction. The sample consists of healthy adult participants with ages 24–64 (within 18–65). Whole-brain results are described in the text and reported with coordinates/figures. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although this is an fMRI study in healthy adults reporting whole-brain task activation maps, the task focuses on emotional (negative) picture processing (IAPS) rather than an explicit social-related task or social-cognitive construct. Inclusion criteria I4 (healthy adult sample), I5 (whole-brain group-level task map), and I6 (results clearly reported) are satisfied. However it does not meet I3 (uses fMRI during a social-related task as defined by the review: affiliation/attachment, social communication, perception/understanding of self/others); the task assesses emotional reactivity to images and a simple person-present button press (attention check) rather than social processing per se. Therefore the study does not address the review objective and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of empathy for pain (a social-related process: perception/understanding of others). Sample: 30 healthy adults aged 18–35, meeting the healthy adult sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and statistical results (main effect of pain and pain×group interactions) with tables of coordinates and corrected/uncorrected thresholds, clearly from the healthy sample. Whole-brain results are reported in tables and described in the text. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all required inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (all male, mean age 23.6) using a social task (viewing dyadic violent interactions) with an orthogonal behavioral task. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., all conditions vs baseline; focus on aggressor vs victim) with statistical maps and cluster-correction details, and includes figures/tables of whole-brain results and connectivity analyses. Thus it meets all required inclusion criteria for the review (fMRI social task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain group-level results clearly reported). No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=26, ages 19–26) that used a task manipulating social content (Social vs Non-social passages) and reports group-level whole-brain task contrasts (Social>Non-social; Vivid>Abstract) with cluster tables and coordinates. The task probes social cognition (theory-of-mind/reasoning about others) and the paper includes behavioral ToM measures and mediation with neural responses. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adults (N=28, ages 30–50) combining explicit self-referential judgments with implicit social stimulus processing (pictures with/without humans). It directly addresses social-related processing (perception/understanding of others) via a social vs non-social contrast and conjunctions. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses are reported (ANOVA across 28 subjects) with FDR-corrected results and cluster thresholds; coordinates and contrasts are provided. Thus it fulfills the review’s requirements for task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults with whole-brain results clearly reported. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, between-group-only, non-adult sample, or non-empirical) are met.

This peer-reviewed empirical study used task-based fMRI (Cyberball social exclusion paradigm) to probe social-related processing (social rejection/affiliation). The sample consists of healthy adult university students (ages ~20, right-handed, n≈42 in final analyses), meeting the healthy adult age criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (exclusion vs. inclusion) with tables of coordinates and whole-brain analyses (see Table 3 and associated figures) and also reports between-group whole-brain contrasts; results are clearly described for the healthy/control sample. Therefore it satisfies the requirements for an fMRI social task in healthy adults with whole-brain reporting.

This is an fMRI task study investigating racial prejudice and disgust perception (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) using a passive face-viewing task. Sample: healthy adult participants (n=26, mean age 21.2) within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task analyses (2×2 ANOVA) with corrected cluster thresholds and tables of activation coordinates (whole-brain results presented in tables/figures/supplement). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6; no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a valence-classification task with social-content stimuli (agency and communion), meeting the review’s definition of social-related processing. The sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=42; ages 18–25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (agency vs. fixation, communion vs. fixation), conjunction analyses, and pairwise contrasts, with AlphaSim correction and coordinates/tables/figures describing results. Thus it provides unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps (reported in text/tables/figures). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, reports healthy adult whole-brain task effects).

This is a task-based fMRI study of social communication (speech act comprehension) in healthy adults. The sample comprises 18 healthy participants aged 18–41. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses with FDR-corrected contrasts (e.g., Request > Naming) and describes whole-brain results in the text and figures; ROI/SVC analyses are supplementary but do not replace whole-brain reporting. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked results (I3, I4, I5, I6). No exclusion criteria were triggered.

This is a task-based fMRI hyperscanning study of joint attention and mutual gaze (social communication/attention). Participants were healthy adults (mean ages ~21–23) within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked results including voxelwise contrasts, statistical maps, and tables of coordinates (with SPM thresholding and anatomical labeling). Behavioral and neural (whole-brain) analyses are reported for the healthy/control participants. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study meets the review inclusion requirements for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This study used task-based fMRI to investigate processing of dynamic social gestures (a social-related task: social communication/perception). The sample comprises healthy participants (described as 20 healthy young adults, mean age 21.4, range 16.9–25.7)—the group contains adults within the 18–65 range and is analyzed as a healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (cluster-corrected Z-stat maps, tables of coordinates, and FDR correction), with results clearly attributed to the healthy participant group. Results are presented as whole-brain maps and coordinate tables in the text/tables. Although the sample is modest and includes one participant slightly under 18, the analyses and reporting meet the review’s requirements for whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of interpersonal social attitude (trust/distrust) control—thus a social-related task using task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (mean age ~20, N=60) meeting the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., attitude > age, trust > age, distrust > age) with FWE-corrected results, tables of coordinates, and figures clearly identified for the healthy/control group. Whole-brain results and ROI/functional connectivity analyses are reported and described in the text and tables. Therefore it satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion requirements.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants that collected whole-brain task-evoked BOLD data while participants viewed faces of other group members to assess neural tracking of sociometric popularity. The task is squarely social (perception/understanding of others; social status/popularity). The paper reports group-level neural activity in valuation and social cognition systems tied to targets’ popularity and describes whole-brain analyses and figures/tables of results. There is no indication of exclusive ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, nor is this a non-empirical paper. Therefore the study meets the review’s requirements for a social fMRI task in healthy adults with whole-brain group results.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition using empathy-evoking film clips (social-related task) with healthy adult participants (N=26, mean age 30.3). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task contrasts and cluster tables/figures (FWE-corrected results) clearly from the healthy sample, and also provides coordinate tables and whole-brain maps. Although effective connectivity (DCM) is reported, whole-brain task activation results are also presented. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This peer-reviewed NeuroImage fMRI study (n=29 healthy adults, ages 18–27) investigates social communication/interaction processing using a task manipulating perceived live vs recorded speech. It reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (Live > Social; Social > Standard) with voxelwise thresholding and cluster correction, and presents whole-brain results in text, figures, and supplementary tables. The sample consists of healthy adults and the whole-brain activation maps are clearly attributed to the healthy/control group. Thus all inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study (Tamir et al., PNAS 2016) in healthy adults (N=20; ages 18–27) that uses a social cognition mentalizing task: participants considered others’ mental states. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain multivariate (searchlight) and univariate maps, cluster-corrected results, and tables of coordinates (e.g., Tables S2/S3), and network-level whole-brain analyses. It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results, and reports healthy-group task effects. Therefore it satisfies the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults investigating social learning (learning about others’ generosity). Participants were healthy adults (N=30 scanned, N=26 included in analyses; ages 19–37). The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts and parametric effects (one-sample t-tests, conjunctions, cluster-corrected results) and provides tables and figures of whole-brain clusters and coordinates. The study therefore meets criteria for an fMRI social task in healthy adults and reports whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps.

The abstract/report lacks essential information to confirm inclusion criteria. Although the study uses fMRI during a social task (live eye contact), the full text provided does not report participant demographics or ages (so I4 cannot be verified) and does not present any group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps or coordinates for a healthy/control group (violating I5). The available content describes network/ROI-style findings (default mode/empathy networks) but gives no evidence of unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task activation results. Therefore it must be excluded for not meeting the whole-brain healthy-group reporting requirement.

Although the study uses simultaneous EEG-fMRI targeting social communication-related processing (right pSTS) and thus addresses the review topic, it appears to report ROI-based correlation analyses between EEG features and activations in the right pSTS rather than providing any group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps for a healthy adult group. The paper is a proof-of-concept conference report focusing on ROI/extraction and correlation methods, with no unmasked whole-brain healthy-group activation results described. Therefore it violates the requirement for whole-brain evidence (I5) and meets exclusion criterion E2 (ROI-only results).

This is an original fMRI study in healthy adult participants (students, mean age 25.7) that used a social-emotion task (guilt memories and hypothetical social scenarios) relevant to social cognition/perception of self and others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (thresholded whole-brain maps at p<0.001 with cluster extent and reported activated regions and coordinates) as well as SVC results. The sample is within the 18–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is empirical fMRI (task-based) and not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets the review inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of affective theory-of-mind (social cognition) in healthy adults (N=21 after QC, mean age 23.7), satisfying the population criterion. The study used task-based fMRI during a social/affective ToM cartoon task and reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (second-level one-sample t-tests) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster results (Tables 1-4), and figures showing activation maps. Whole-brain results for the healthy/control group are clearly described; coordinate tables and cluster statistics are provided. Although ROI and PPI analyses are also reported, whole-brain task activation maps and coordinates are present. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI experiment investigating processing of empathic vs. unempathic social responses (social cognition / perception and understanding of others). The sample comprises 20 healthy adult participants (mean age 26), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and voxelwise results (tables with MNI coordinates, FWE-corrected clusters, and whole-brain contrasts such as EE>EN, CE>baseline, negative>positive feedback). Results are not limited to ROI, resting-state, or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly reported. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of perception of facial expressions (a social communication / perception-of-others task) in healthy adult participants (n=24, mean age 25.2). The paper reports group-level fMRI analyses (mixed-effects FLAME), parameter estimate maps registered to MNI space, and a group-level localiser contrast (faces > scrambled faces) used to define face-selective regions, i.e., whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts from healthy participants. Results include group-level statistical analyses and whole-brain-based anatomical region comparisons. Thus the study meets the review’s requirements for a task-based social fMRI study in healthy adults and reports group-level whole-brain results.

This is an fMRI study (NeuroImage, 2016) using a social-evaluative task (watching approving/disapproving videos). The sample comprises 37 healthy adult participants (mean age 24.8). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (negative>neutral, positive>neutral), a conjunction analysis, whole-brain FWE-corrected results, and coordinate tables/figures (Tables 2–4, Figs. 3–5). Results are clearly presented for the healthy/control group. Therefore it satisfies I3, I4, I5 and I6 and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition: participants (N=30 healthy, right-handed White adults, age 18–29) completed an fMRI face-perception task and later trustworthiness ratings. The task probes perception/understanding of others (race perception/trustworthiness), meeting the social-related task requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (e.g., Black > White contrasts; covariate analyses) and provides tables of peak coordinates (Tables 2 and 3) and statistical maps, satisfying whole-brain reporting. Results for the healthy adult sample are reported directly. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (I3, I4, I5, I6) and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (person perception and person knowledge) using a task manipulating bodies vs names and trait vs neutral statements, addressing social cognition. Participants are healthy adults (N=21, mean age 24.6), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked univariate contrasts (e.g., Bodies>Names, Traits>Neutral, interaction [(BodiesTraits>BodiesNeutral)>(NamesTraits>NamesNeutral)]) with coordinates, thresholds, and overlaps with localisers; these satisfy the requirement for whole-brain voxelwise results. Whole-brain results are described in the text and figures/tables. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, they are not the sole analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of theory-of-mind/social cognition in healthy adults (N=24, mean age 25.7) that directly examines social processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects task contrasts (e.g., social>non-social in Background; unexpected>expected in Outcome) with tables of peak MNI coordinates and cluster statistics, and ROI/MVPA analyses. Healthy adult results are reported explicitly and not limited to a clinical subgroup. Thus the study meets inclusion criteria: uses fMRI for social-related tasks (I3); includes healthy adult participants within 18–65 (I4); reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise maps/contrasts (I5); and provides whole-brain results in tables/figures (I6). No exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=23, ages 21–43) that used a task requiring social judgments of faces (social cognition). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (Social Judgment > Perceptual Judgment) with FWE-corrected cluster results presented in tables and figures, and extracts whole-cluster eigenvariates for regression analyses. All required elements for inclusion are present: task-based fMRI of a social-related construct, a healthy adult sample within 18–65, and clearly reported whole-brain group results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, non-empirical, or out-of-range samples) are met. Therefore the study meets the review’s inclusion criteria and is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=25, mean age 24) that explicitly probes social-related processing: participants evaluated LEGO models for meaning (social/semantic properties) versus physical properties and contrasts include own vs other and collective vs individual. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and peak coordinates (Table 1) with appropriate correction (FDR/FWE) for several contrasts (e.g., meaning > physical, own > other), satisfying whole-brain reporting. Methods, participants, and contrasts are clearly described for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an fMRI study using the Cyberball ball-toss social interaction task (a social-related paradigm assessing social reward/interaction). Participants were healthy adults (final N=31, mean age ~21, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., ball-toss [high-frequency – normal-frequency] > button-press [high-frequency – normal-frequency]) with peak coordinates and cluster-level FWE-corrected statistics, clearly from the healthy/control group. Results are presented as whole-brain maps/coordinates in text/tables. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion requirements for the review.

This study reports task-state fMRI focused on episodic memory retrieval and functional connectivity of self-referential, executive and salience sub-networks in aMCI and control participants. However, it does not present a group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group; analyses are ROI- and seed-based functional connectivity (correlation/Fisher z) and network-level conjunctions rather than unmasked whole-brain task activation contrasts. Therefore it meets exclusion criterion E3 (seed-based/connectivity-only results without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map). Although the paper discusses self-referential processing (a social-related construct), the primary analyses are connectivity-based, so it fails the whole-brain task-activation requirement (I5) and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study that directly investigates socially-induced emotion regulation (Social-Reg) — a clearly social-related task involving affiliation/attachment and social cognition. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (female, ages 22–32) and group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts are reported (e.g., Social-Reg > Social-Look) with tables of coordinates and cluster-level statistics (Tables 1–3 and figures). Resting-state and Self-Reg controls are also present but do not preclude the reporting of unmasked whole-brain task activations for the healthy group. Thus the paper meets all required inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study using a social interaction task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) probing retaliatory aggression, which fits the review’s social-related processing scope. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=15, mean age 22.3), meeting the age and healthy-sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses including voxelwise statistical maps, cluster thresholds, and Talairach coordinates (reported in tables and figures), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented (within-group contrasts and parametric modulation analyses). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state-only, between-group-only contrasts, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical work) apply. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition using an interactive Prisoner’s Dilemma task that elicits mentalizing (a social-related construct). The sample includes healthy adults (n=195 for behavioral/structural analyses; n=163 for fMRI), ages 19–38, meeting the adult healthy participant criterion. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (ment > cont) analyzed with SPM8 and reports cluster- and FWE-corrected results, tables of significant clusters/coordinates, and whole-brain activation maps for the healthy sample. Thus it provides the required healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps and coordinate tables. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical, out-of-range participants, or only between-group contrasts without healthy-group task maps) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processes (charitable giving, empathy, perspective taking) in healthy adult participants (N=33, ages 20–34). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (searchlight MVPA and GLM contrasts) with corrected statistical thresholds (p<0.05 FWE) and tables/figures of results. The methods and results clearly present healthy-group task-evoked whole-brain effects. Thus it meets the review’s criteria for inclusion.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in a large sample of healthy adults (N=178, mean age 40.9, within 18–65). The task (EmpaToM) manipulates empathy and Theory of Mind and constitutes a social-related task. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (emotional vs neutral videos; ToM vs non-ToM questions/videos) and provides activation tables/coordinates and figures clearly derived from the healthy/control group. Whole-brain results are explicitly described in text, tables, and figures. Though additional connectivity/DCM analyses are reported, whole-brain task activation is present and clearly reported for the healthy sample, meeting the inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final N=18, ages 21–38) examining social cognition (cooperation vs. competition). The task is social and theory-of-mind related, and the paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task activation results (univariate whole-brain contrasts with cluster tables and coordinates) as well as ROI and MVPA analyses. Thus it satisfies the review's requirements for fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults with reported whole-brain results.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults: participants (n=18, mean age 23.7) performed a social inference task (inferring targets' emotions) during fMRI, meeting the review’s social-related task requirement. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise GLM analyses (conjunctions, contrasts) with tables of coordinates and figures describing results for the healthy sample. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of impression updating—a social-cognitive task (perception/understanding of others). Participants were healthy adults (N=21, ages 18–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., L2>F3; interaction and targeted whole-brain contrasts) with tables of peak coordinates and figures, corrected for multiple comparisons. Whole-brain results are clearly described for the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review (I3, I4, I5, I6) and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition) in healthy adults (n=19, ages 20–53). The REMICS task explicitly manipulates social vs. physical scenarios and contextual adjustments, and the paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., SocAdj > PhyConf; Soc > Phy; Adj > Conf) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster statistics, and figures showing whole-brain activations. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately. The study therefore meets the review objective and satisfies the whole-brain reporting requirement (coordinates/tables acceptable). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (mean age ~31) that uses the Ultimatum Game, a social economic exchange task probing social decision-making and cooperation. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (random-effects ANOVA, conjunction analyses, whole-brain parametric regressions) with coordinates and corrected statistics, clearly from the healthy participant groups. Methods and results provide whole-brain statistical maps and coordinate tables. Thus it meets the meta-analysis objective and inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The study uses fMRI during social tasks in healthy adults (theory-of-mind and social attribution-of-attention) and meets I3 and I4. However, it does not report a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise activation map for the healthy group. Task-related analyses were performed using localized ICA within a TPJ ROI (ROI-limited task decomposition) and task relevance was assessed via IC time-course regressions; whole-brain results are limited to seed-to-voxel functional connectivity maps (connectivity, not task-evoked activation). Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain task activation reporting and meets exclusion criteria E2 and E3.
